persaliases.persname: Both Fourth and Fifth Roman Citizens
Both Fourth and Fifth Roman Citizens

scene.stagedir: Enter a Company of Mutinous Citizens, with Staues, Clubs, and other weapons

speech.speaker: 1. Citizen.
speech.line: Before we proceed any further, heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Speake, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: You are all reſolu’d rather to dy then
to famiſh?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Reſolu’d, reſolu’d.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Firſt you know, Caius Martius is chiefe enemy
to the people.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: We know’t, we know’t.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Let vs kill him, and wee’l haue Corne at our own
price. Is’t a Verdiƈt?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: No more talking on’t; Let it be done, away, away

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: One word, good Citizens.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: We are accounted poore Citizens, the Patri—
cians good: what Authority ſurfets one, would releeue
vs. If they would yeelde vs but the ſuperfluitie while it
were wholſome, wee might gueſſe they releeued vs hu—
manely: But they thinke we are too deere, the leanneſſe
that affliƈts vs, the obieƈt of our miſery, is as an inuento—
ry to particularize their abundance, our ſufferance is a
gaine to them. Let vs reuenge this with our Pikes, ere
we become Rakes. For the Gods know, I ſpeake this in
hunger for Bread, not in thirſt for Reuenge.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Would you proceede eſpecially againſt Caius
Martius.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Againſt him firſt: He’s a very dog to the Com—
monalty.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Conſider you what Seruices he ha’s done for his
Country?

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Very well, and could bee content to giue him
good report for’t, but that hee payes himſelfe with bee—
ing proud.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Nay, but ſpeak not maliciouſly.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: I ſay vnto you, what he hath done Famouſlie,
he did it to that end: though ſoft conſcienc’d men can be
content to ſay it was for his Countrey, he did it to pleaſe
his Mother, and to be partly proud, which he is, euen to
the altitude of his vertue.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: What he cannot helpe in his Nature, you ac—
count a Vice in him: You muſt in no way ſay he is co—
uetous.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: If I muſt not, I neede not be barren of Accuſa—
tions he hath faults (with ſurplus) to tyre in repetition.
What ſhowts are theſe? The other ſide a’th City is riſen:
why ſtay we prating heere? To th’Capitoll.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Come, come.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Soft, who comes heere?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Worthy Menenius Agrippa, one that hath al—
wayes lou’d the people.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: He’s one honeſt enough, wold al the reſt wer ſo.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: What work’s my Countrimen in hand?
Where go you with Bats and Clubs? The matter
Speake I pray you.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: Our buſines is not vnknowne to th’Senat, they
haue had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, ẃ
now wee’l ſhew em in deeds: they ſay poore Suters haue
ſtrong breaths, they ſhal know we haue ſtrong arms too.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Why Maſters, my good Friends, mine honeſt
Neighbours, will you vndo your ſelues?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: We cannot Sir, we are vndone already.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I tell you Friends, moſt charitable care
Haue the Patricians of you for your wants.
Your ſuffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the Heauen with your ſtaues, as lift them
Againſt the Roman State, whoſe courſe will on
The way it takes: cracking ten thouſand Curbes
Of more ſtrong linke aſſunder, then can euer
Appeare in your impediment. For the Dearth,
The Gods, not the Patricians make it, and
Your knees to them (not armes) muſt helpe. Alacke,
You are tranſported by Calamity
Thether, where more attends you, and you ſlander
The Helmes o’th State; who care for you like Fathers,
When you curſe them, as Enemies.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: Care for vs? True indeed, they nere car’d for vs
yet. Suffer vs to famiſh, and their Store-houſes cramm’d
with Graine: Make Ediƈts for Vſurie, to ſupport Vſu—
rers; repeale daily any wholſome Aƈt eſtabliſhed againſt
the rich, and prouide more piercing Statutes daily, to
chaine vp and reſtraine the poore. If the Warres eate vs
not vppe, they will; and there’s all the loue they beare
vs.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Either you muſt
Confeſſe your ſelues wondrous Malicious,
Or be accus’d of Folly. I ſhall tell you
A pretty Tale, it may be you haue heard it,
But ſince it ſerues my purpoſe, I will venture
To ſcale’t a little more.

speech.speaker: 2 Citizen.
speech.line: Well,
Ile heare it Sir: yet you muſt not thinke
To fobbe off our diſgrace with a tale:
But and’t pleaſe you deliuer.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: There was a time, when all the bodies members
Rebell’d againſt the Belly; thus accus’d it:
That onely like a Gulfe it did remaine
I’th midd’ſt a th’body, idle and vnaƈtiue,
Still cubbording the Viand, neuer bearing
Like labour with the reſt, where th’other Inſtruments
Did ſee, and heare, deuiſe, inſtruƈt, walke, feele,
And mutually participate, did miniſter
Vnto the appetite; and affeƈtion common
Of the whole body, the Belly anſwer’d.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Well ſir, what anſwer made the Belly.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Sir, I ſhall tell you with a kinde of Smile,
Which ne’re came from the Lungs, but euen thus:
For looke you I may make the belly Smile,
As well as ſpeake, it taintingly replyed
To’th’diſcontented Members, the mutinous parts
That enuied his receite: euen ſo moſt fitly,
As you maligne our Senators, for that
They are not ſuch as you.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Your Bellies anſwer: What
The Kingly crown’d head, the vigilant eye,
The Counſailor Heart, the Arme our Souldier,
Our Steed the Legge, the Tongue our Trumpeter,
With other Muniments and petty helpes
In this our Fabricke, if that they—

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: What then? Foreme, this Fellow ſpeakes.
What then? What then?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Should by the Cormorant belly be reſtrain’d,
Who is the ſinke a th’body.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Well, what then?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: The former Agents, if they did complaine,
What could the Belly anſwer?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I will tell you,
If you’l beſtow a ſmall (of what you haue little)
Patience awhile; you’ſt heare the Bellies anſwer.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Y’are long about it.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Note me this good Friend;
Your moſt graue Belly was deliberate,
Not raſh like his Accuſers, and thus anſwered.
True is it my Incorporate Friends (quoth he)
That I receiue the generall Food at firſt
Which you do liue vpon: and fit it is,
Becauſe I am the Store-houſe, and the Shop
Of the whole Body. But, if you do remember,
I ſend it through the Riuers of your blood
Euen to the Court, the Heart, to th’ſeate o’th’Braine,
And through the Crankes and Offices of man,
The ſtrongeſt Nerues, and ſmall inferiour Veines
From me receiue that naturall competencie
Whereby they liue. And though that all at once
(You my good Friends, this ſayes the Belly) marke me.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: I ſir, well, well.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Though all at once, cannot
See what I do deliuer out to each,
Yet I can make my Awdit vp, that all
From me do backe receiue the Flowre of all,
And leaue me but the Bran. What ſay you too’t?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: It was an anſwer, how apply you this?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: The Senators of Rome, are this good Belly,
And you the mutinous Members: For examine
Their Counſailes, and their Cares; diſgeſt things rightly,
Touching the Weale a’th Common, you ſhall finde
No publique benefit which you receiue
But it proceeds, or comes from them to you,
And no way from your ſelues. What do you thinke?
You, the great Tœ of this Aſſembly?

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: I the great Tœ? Why the great Tœ?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: For that being one o’th loweſt, baſeſt, pooreſt
Of this moſt wiſe Rebellion, thou gœſt formoſt:
Thou Raſcall, that art worſt in blood to run,
Lead’ſt firſt to win ſome vantage.
But make you ready your ſtiffe bats and clubs,
Rome, and her Rats, are at the point of battell,
The one ſide muſt haue baile.
Hayle, Noble Martius.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thanks. What’s the matter you diſſentious rogues
That rubbing the poore Itch of your Opinion,
Make your ſelues Scabs.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: We haue euer your good word.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: He that will giue good words to thee, wil flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you haue, you Curres,
That like nor Peace, nor Warre? The one affrights you,
The other makes you proud. He that truſts to you,
Where he ſhould finde you Lyons, findes you Hares:
Where Foxes, Geeſe you are: No ſurer, no,
Then is the coale of fire vpon the Ice,
Or Hailſtone in the Sun. Your Vertue is,
To make him worthy, whoſe offence ſubdues him,
And curſe that Iuſtice did it. Who deſerues Greatnes,
Deſerues your Hate: and your Affeƈtions are
A ſickmans Appetite; who deſires moſt that
Which would encreaſe his euill. He that depends
Vpon your fauours, ſwimmes with finnes of Leade,
And hewes downe Oakes, with ruſhes. Hang ye: truſt ye?
With euery Minute you do change a Minde,
And call him Noble, that was now your Hate:
Him vilde, that was your Garland. What’s the matter,
That in theſe ſeuerall places of the Citie,
You cry againſt the Noble Senate, who
(Vnder the Gods) keepe you in awe, which elſe
Would feede on one another? What’s their ſeeking?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: For Corne at their owne rates, wherof they ſay
The Citie is well ſtor’d.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Hang ’em: They ſay?
They’l ſit by th’fire, and preſume to know
What’s done i’th Capitoll: Who’s like to riſe,
Who thriues, & who declines: Side faƈtions, & giue out
Conieƈturall Marriages, making parties ſtrong,
And feebling ſuch as ſtand not in their liking,
Below their cobled Shoœs. They ſay ther’s grain enough?
Would the Nobility lay aft aſide their ruth,
And let me vſe my Sword, I’de make a Quarrie
With thouſands of theſe quarter’d ſlaues, as high
As I could picke my Lance.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Nay theſe are almoſt thoroughly perſwaded:
For though abundantly they lacke diſcretion
Yet are they paſsing Cowardly. But I beſeech you,
What ſayes the other Troope?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: They are diſſolu’d: Hang em;
They ſaid they were an hungry, ſigh’d forth Prouerbes
That Hunger-broke ſtone wals: that dogges muſt eate
That meate was made for mouths. That the gods ſent not
Corne for the Richmen onely: With theſe ſhreds
They vented their Complainings, which being anſwer’d
And a petition granted them, a ſtrange one,
To breake the heart of generoſity,
And make bold power looke pale, they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the hornes a’th Moone,
Shooting their Emulation.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: What is graunted them?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Fiue Tribunes to defend their vulgar wiſdoms
Of their owne choice. One’s Iunius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. Sdeath,
The rabble ſhould haue firſt vnroo’ſt the City
Ere ſo preuayl’d with me; it will in time
Win vpon power, and throw forth greater Theames
For Inſurreƈtions arguing.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: This is ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Go get you home you Fragments.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Where’s Caius Martius?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Heere: what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: The newes is ſir, the Volcies are in Armes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I am glad on’t, then we ſhall ha meanes to vent
Our muſtie ſuperfluity. See our beſt Elders.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sicinius Velutus, Annius Brutus Cominius, Titus Lartius, with other Senatours.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Martius ’tis true, that you haue lately told vs,
The Volces are in Armes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: They haue a Leader,
Tullus Auffidius that will put you too’t:
I ſinne in enuying his Nobility:
And were I any thing but what I am,
I would wiſh me onely he.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: You haue fought together?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Were halfe to halfe the world by th’eares, & he
vpon my partie, I’de reuolt to make
Onely my warres with him. He is a Lion
That I am proud to hunt.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Then worthy Martius,
Attend vpon Cominius to theſe Warres.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: It is your former promiſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sir it is,
And I am conſtant: Titus Lucius, thou
Shalt ſee me once more ſtrike at Tullus face.
What art thou ſtiffe? Stand’ſt out?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: No Caius Martius,
Ile leane vpon one Crutch, and fight with tother,
Ere ſtay behinde this Buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Oh true-bred.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: Your Company to’th’Capitoll, where I know
Our greateſt Friends attend vs.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Lead you on: Follow Cominius, we muſt followe
you, right worthy your Priority.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Noble Martius.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: Hence to your homes, be gone.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nay let them follow,
The Volces haue much Corne: take theſe Rats thither,
To gnaw their Garners. Worſhipfull Mutiners,
Your valour puts well forth: Pray follow.

scene.stagedir: Citizens ſteale away. Manet Sicin. & Brutus.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Was euer man ſo proud as is this Martius?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He has no equall.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: When we were choſen Tribunes for the people.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Mark’d you his lip and eyes.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Nay, but his taunts.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Being mou’d, he will not ſpare to gird the Gods.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Bemocke the modeſt Moone.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: The preſent Warres deuoure him, he is growne
Too proud to be ſo valiant.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Such a Nature, tickled with good ſucceſſe, diſ—
daines the ſhadow which he treads on at noone, but I do
wonder, his inſolence can brooke to be commanded vn—
der Cominius?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Fame, at the which he aymes,
In whom already he’s well grac’d, cannot
Better be held, nor more attain’d then by
A place below the firſt: for what miſcarries
Shall be the Generals fault, though he performe
To th’vtmoſt of a man, and giddy cenſure
Will then cry out of Martius: Oh, if he
Had borne the buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Beſides, if things go well,
Opinion that ſo ſtickes on Martius, ſhall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Come: halfe all Cominius Honors are to Martius
Though Martius earn’d them not: and all his faults
To Martius ſhall be Honors, though indeed
In ought he merit not.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Let’s hence, and heare
How the diſpatch is made, and in what faſhion
More then his ſingularity, he gœs
Vpon this preſent Aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Bru
speech.line: Let’s along.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tullus Auffidius with Senators of Coriolus.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: So, your opinion is Auffidius,
That they of Rome are entred in our Counſailes,
And know how we proceede,

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Is it not yours?
What euer haue bin thought one in this State
That could be brought to bodily aƈt, ere Rome
Had circumuention: ’tis not foure dayes gone
Since I heard thence, theſe are the words, I thinke
I haue the Letter heere: yes, heere it is;
They haue preſt a Power, but it is not knowne
Whether for Eaſt or Weſt: the Dearth is great,
The people Mutinous: And it is rumour’d,
Cominius, Martius your old Enemy
(Who is of Rome worſe hated then of you)
And Titus Lartius, a moſt valiant Roman,
Theſe three leade on this Preparation
Whether ’tis bent: moſt likely, ’tis for you:
Conſider of it.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Our Armie’s in the Field:
We neuer yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To anſwer vs.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Nor did you thinke it folly,
To keepe your great pretences vayl’d, till when
They needs muſt ſhew themſelues, which in the hatching
It ſeem’d appear’d to Rome. By the diſcouery,
We ſhalbe ſhortned in our ayme, which was
To take in many Townes, ere (almoſt) Rome
Should know we were a-foot.

speech.speaker: 2.Sen.
speech.line: Noble Auffidius,
Take your Commiſſion, hye you to your Bands,
Let vs alone’to guard Corioles
If they ſet downe before’s: for the remoue
Bring vp your Army: but (I thinke) you’l finde
Th’haue not prepar’d for vs.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: O doubt not that,
I ſpeake from Certainties. Nay more,
Some parcels of their Power are forth already,
And onely hitherward. I leaue your Honors.
If we, and Caius Martius chance to meete,
’Tis ſworne betweene vs, we ſhall euer ſtrike
Till one can do no more.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: The Gods aſsiſt you.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: And keepe your Honors ſafe.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: 2.Sen.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Volumnia and Virgilia, mother and wife to Martius: They ſet them downe on two lowe ſtooles and ſowe.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I pray you daughter ſing, or expreſſe your ſelfe
in a more comfortable ſort: If my Sonne were my Huſ—
band, I ſhould freelier reioyce in that abſence wherein
he wonne Honor, then in the embracements of his Bed,
where he would ſhew moſt loue. When yet hee was but
tender-bodied, and the onely Sonne of my womb; when
youth with comelineſſe pluck’d all gaze his way; when
for a day of Kings entreaties, a Mother ſhould not ſel him
an houre from her beholding; I conſidering how Honour
would become ſuch a perſon, that it was no better then
Piƈture-like to hang by th’wall, if renowne made it not
ſtirre, was pleas’d to let him ſeeke danger, where he was
like to finde fame: To a cruell Warre I ſent him, from
whence he return’d, his browes bound with Oake. I tell
thee Daughter, I ſprang not more in ioy at firſt hearing
he was a Man-child, then now in firſt ſeeing he had pro—
ued himſelfe a man.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: But had he died in the Buſineſſe Madame, how
then?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Then his good report ſhould haue beene my
Sonne, I therein would haue found iſſue. Heare me pro—
feſſe ſincerely, had I a dozen ſons each in my loue alike,
and none leſſe deere then thine, and my good Martius, I
had rather had eleuen dye Nobly for their Countrey, then
one voluptuouſly ſurfet out of Aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to viſit you.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: Beſeech you giue me leaue to retire my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Indeed you ſhall not:
Me thinkes, I heare hither your Husbands Drumme:
See him plucke Auffidius downe by th’haire:
(As children from a Beare) the Volces ſhunning him:
Me thinkes I ſee him ſtampe thus, and call thus,
Come on you Cowards, you were got in feare
Though you were borne in Rome; his bloody brow
With his mail’d hand, then wiping, forth he gœs
Like to a Harueſt man, that task’d to mowe
Or all, or looſe his hyre.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: His bloody Brow? Oh Iupiter, no blood.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Away you Foole; it more becomes a man
Then gilt his Trophe. The breſts of Hecuba
When ſhe did ſuckle Heƈtor, look’d not louelier
Then Heƈtors forhead, when it ſpit forth blood
At Grecian ſword. Contenning, tell Valeria
We are fit to bid her welcome.

speech.speaker: Vir.
speech.line: Heauens bleſſe my Lord from fell Auffidius.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Hee’l beat Auffidius head below his knee,
And treade vpon his necke.

scene.stagedir: Enter Valeria with an Vſher, and a Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: My Ladies both good day to you.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Sweet Madam.

speech.speaker: Vir.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your Ladyſhip.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: How do you both? You are manifeſt houſe-kee—
pers. What are you ſowing heere? A fine ſpotte in good
faith. How dœs your little Sonne?

speech.speaker: Vir.
speech.line: I thanke your Lady-ſhip: Well good Madam.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: He had rather ſee the ſwords, and heare a Drum,
then looke vpon his Schoolmaſter.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: A my word the Fathers Sonne: Ile ſweare ’tis a
very pretty boy. A my troth, I look’d vpon him a Wenſ—
day halfe an houre together: ha’s ſuch a confirm’d coun—
tenance. I ſaw him run after a gilded Butterfly, & when
he caught it, he let it go againe, and after it againe, and o—
uer and ouer he comes, and vp againe: catcht it again: or
whether his fall enrag’d him, or how ’twas, hee did ſo ſet
his teeth, and teare it. Oh, I warrant how he mammockt
it.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: One on’s Fathers moods.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Indeed la, tis a Noble childe.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: A Cracke Madam.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Come, lay aſide your ſtitchery, I muſt haue you
play the idle Huſwife with me this afternoone.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: No (good Madam)
I will not out of doores.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Not out of doores?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: She ſhall, ſhe ſhall.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: Indeed no, by your patience; Ile not ouer the
threſhold, till my Lord returne from the Warres.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Fye, you confine your ſelfe moſt vnreaſonably:
Come, you muſt go viſit the good Lady that lies in.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: I will wiſh her ſpeedy ſtrength, and viſite her
with my prayers: but I cannot go thither.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Why I pray you.

speech.speaker: Vlug.
speech.line: ’Tis not to ſaue labour, nor that I want loue.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: You would be another Penelope: yet they ſay, all
the yearne ſhe ſpun in Vliſſes abſence, did but fill Athica
full of Mothes. Come, I would your Cambrick were ſen—
ſible as your finger, that you might leaue pricking it for
pitie. Come you ſhall go with vs.

speech.speaker: Vir.
speech.line: No good Madam, pardon me, indeed I will not
foorth.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: In truth la go with me, and Ile tell you excellent
newes of your Husband.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: Oh good Madam, there can be none yet.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Verily I do not ieſt with you: there came newes
from him laſt night.

speech.speaker: Vir.
speech.line: Indeed Madam.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: In earneſt it’s true; I heard a Senatour ſpeake it.
Thus it is: the Volcies haue an Army forth, againſt whō
Cominius the Generall is gone, with one part of our Ro—
mane power. Your Lord, and Titus Lartius, are ſet down
before their Citie Carioles, they nothing doubt preuai—
ling, and to make it breefe Warres. This is true on mine
Honor, and ſo I pray go with vs.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: Giue me excuſe good Madame, I will obey you
in euery thing heereafter.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Let her alone Ladie, as ſhe is now:
She will but diſeaſe our better mirth.

speech.speaker: Valeria.
speech.line: In troth I thinke ſhe would:
Fare you well then. Come good ſweet Ladie.
Prythee Virgilia turne thy ſolemneſſe out a doore,
And go along with vs.

speech.speaker: Virgil.
speech.line: No
At a word Madam; Indeed I muſt not,
I wiſh you much mirth.

speech.speaker: Val
speech.line: Well, then farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Martius, Titus Lartius, with Drumme and Colours, with Captaines and Souldiers, as before the City Corialus: to them a Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: Yonder comes Newes:
A Wager they haue met.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: My horſe to yours, no.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Tis done.

speech.speaker: Lart.
speech.line: Agreed.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Say, ha’s our Generall met the Enemy?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: They lye in view, but haue not ſpoke as yet.

speech.speaker: Lart.
speech.line: So, the good Horſe is mine.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Ile buy him of you.

speech.speaker: Lart.
speech.line: No, Ile nor ſel, nor giue him: Lend you him I will
For halfe a hundred yeares: Summon the Towne.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: How farre off lie theſe Armies?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Within this mile and halfe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Then ſhall we heare their Larum, & they Ours.
Now Mars, I prythee make vs quicke in worke,
That we with ſmoaking ſwords may march from hence
To helpe our fielded Friends. Come, blow thy blaſt.
speech.stagedir: They Sound a Parley: Enter two Senators with others on the Walles of Corialus.
speech.line: Tullus Auffidious, is he within your Walles?

speech.speaker: 1.Senat.
speech.line: No, nor a man that feares you leſſe then he,
That’s leſſer then a little:
Hearke, our Drummes
Are bringing forth our youth: Wee’l breake our Walles
Rather then they ſhall pound vs vp our Gates,
Which yet ſeeme ſhut, we haue but pin’d with Ruſhes,
They’le open of themſelues. Harke you, farre off
There is Auffidious. Liſt what worke he makes
Among’ſt your clouen Army.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Oh they are at it.

speech.speaker: Lart.
speech.line: Their noiſe be our inſtruƈtion. Ladders hoa.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Army of the Volces.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: They feare vs not, but iſſue forth their Citie.
Now put your Shields before your hearts, and fight
With hearts more proofe then Shields.
Aduance braue Titus,
They do diſdaine vs much beyond our Thoughts,
which makes me ſweat with wrath. Come on my fellows
He that retires, Ile take him for a Volce,
And he ſhall feele mine edge.

scene.stagedir: Alarum, the Romans are beat back to their Trenches Enter Martius Curſing.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: All the contagion of the South, light on you,
You Shames of Rome: you Heard of Byles and Plagues
Plaiſter you o’re, that you may be abhorr’d
Farther then ſeene, and one infeƈt another
Againſt the Winde a mile: you ſoules of Geeſe,
That beare the ſhapes of men, how haue you run
From Slaues, that Apes would beate; Pluto and Hell,
All hurt behinde, backes red, and faces pale
With flight and agued feare, mend and charge home,
Or by the fires of heauen, Ile leaue the Fœ,
And make my Warres on you: Looke too’t: Come on,
If you’l ſtand faſt, wee’l beate them to their Wiues,
As they vs to our Trenches followes.
speech.stagedir: Another Alarum, and Martius followes them to gates, and is ſhut in.
speech.line: So, now the gates are ope: now proue good Seconds,
’Tis for the followers Fortune, widens them,
Not for the flyers: Marke me, and do the like.

speech.speaker: 1.Sol.
speech.line: Foole-hardineſſe, not I.

speech.speaker: 2.Sol.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: 1.Sol.
speech.line: See they haue ſhut him in.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: To th’pot I warrant him.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: What is become of Martius?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Slaine (Sir) doubtleſſe.

speech.speaker: 1.Sol.
speech.line: Following the Flyers at the very heeles,
With them he enters: who vpon the ſodaine
Clapt to their Gates, he is himſelfe alone,
To anſwer all the City.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: Oh Noble Fellow!
Who ſenſibly out-dares his ſenceleſſe Sword,
And when it bowes, ſtand’ſt vp: Thou art left Martius,
A Carbuncle intire: as big as thou art
Weare not ſo rich a Iewell. Thou was’t a Souldier
Euen to Calues wiſh, not fierce and terrible
Onely in ſtrokes, but with thy grim lookes, and
The Thunder-like percuſſion of thy ſounds
Thou mad’ſt thine enemies ſhake, as if the World
Were Feauorous, and did tremble.

scene.stagedir: Enter Martius bleeding, aſſaulted by the Enemy.

speech.speaker: 1.Sol.
speech.line: Looke Sir.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: O ’tis Martius.
Let’s fetch him off, or make remaine alike.

scene.stagedir: They fight, and all enter the City.

speech.speaker: 1.Rom.
speech.line: This will I carry to Rome.

speech.speaker: 2.Rom.
speech.line: And I this.

speech.speaker: 3.Rom
speech.line: A Murrain on’t, I tooke this for Siluer.

scene.stagedir: Enter Martius, and Titus with a Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: See heere theſe mouers, that do prize their hours
At a crack’d Drachme: Cuſhions, Leaden Spoones,
Irons of a Doit, Dublets that Hangmen would
Bury with thoſe that wore them. Theſe baſe ſlaues,
Ere yet the fight be done, packe vp, downe with them.
And harke, what noyſe the Generall makes: To him
There is the man of my ſoules hate, Auffidious,
Piercing our Romanes: Then Valiant Titus take
Conuenient Numbers to make good the City,
Whil’ſt I with thoſe that haue the ſpirit, wil haſte
To helpe Cominius.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: Worthy Sir, thou bleed’ſt,
Thy exerciſe hath bin too violent,
For a ſecond courſe of Fight.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sir, praiſe me not:
My worke hath yet not warm’d me. Fare you well:
The blood I drop, is rather Phyſicall
Then dangerous to me: To Auffidious thus, I will appear and fight.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: Now the faire Goddeſſe Fortune,
Fall deepe in loue with thee, and her great charmes
Miſguide thy Oppoſers ſwords, Bold Gentleman:
Proſperity be thy Page.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thy Friend no leſſe,
Then thoſe ſhe placeth higheſt: So farewell.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: Thou worthieſt Martius,
Go ſound thy Trumpet in the Market place,
Call thither all the Officers a’th’Towne,
Where they ſhall know our minde. Away.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cominius as it were in retire, with ſoldiers.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Breath you my friends, wel fought, we are come off,
Like Romans, neither fooliſh in our ſtands,
Nor Cowardly in retyre: Beleeue me Sirs,
We ſhall be charg’d againe. Whiles we haue ſtrooke
By Interims and conueying guſts, we haue heard
The Charges of our Friends. The Roman Gods,
Leade their ſucceſſes, as we wiſh our owne,
That both our powers, with ſmiling Fronts encountring,
May giue you thankfull Sacrifice. Thy Newes?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: The Cittizens of Corioles haue yſſued,
And giuen to Lartius and to Martius Battaile:
I ſaw our party to their Trenches driuen,
And then I came away.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Though thou ſpeakeſt truth,
Me thinkes thou ſpeak’ſt not well. How long is’t ſince?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Aboue an houre, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: ’Tis not a mile: briefely we heard their drummes.
How could’ſt thou in a mile confound an houre,
And bring thy Newes ſo late?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Spies of the Volces
Held me in chace, that I was forc’d to wheele
Three or foure miles about, elſe had I ſir
Halfe an houre ſince brought my report.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Whoſe yonder,
That dœ’s appeare as he were Flead? O Gods,
He has the ſtampe of Martius, and I haue
Before time ſeene him thus.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Come I too late?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: The Shepherd knowes not Thunder frō a Taber,
More then I know the ſound of Martius Tongue
From euery meaner man.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: Come I too late?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your owne.

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Oh! let me clip ye
In Armes as ſound, as when I woo’d in heart;
As merry, as when our Nuptiall day was done,
And Tapers burnt to Bedward.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Flower of Warriors, how is’t with Titus Lartius?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: As with a man buſied about Decrees:
Condemning ſome to death, and ſome to exile,
Ranſoming him, or pittying, threatning th’other;
Holding Corioles in the name of Rome,
Euen like a fawning Grey-hound in the Leaſh,
To let him ſlip at will.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Where is that Slaue
Which told me they had beate you to your Trenches?
Where is he? Call him hither.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Let him alone,
He did informe the truth: but for our Gentlemen,
The common file, (a plague-Tribunes for them)
The Mouſe ne’re ſhunn’d the Cat, as they did budge
From Raſcals worſe then they.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: But how preuail’d you?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Will the time ſerue to tell, I do not thinke:
Where is the enemy? Are you Lords a’th Field?
If not, why ceaſe you till you are ſo?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Martius, we haue at diſaduantage fought,
And did retyre to win our purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: How lies their Battell? Know you on ẃ ſide
They haue plac’d their men of truſt?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: As I gueſſe Martius,
Their Bands i’th Vaward are the Antients
Of their beſt truſt: O’re them Auffidious,
Their very heart of Hope.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I do beſeech you,
By all the Battailes wherein we haue fought,
By th’Blood we haue ſhed together,
By th’Vowes we haue made
To endure Friends, that you direƈtly ſet me
Againſt Affidious, and his Antiats,
And that you not delay the preſent (but
Filling the aire with Swords aduanc’d) and Darts,
We proue this very houre.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Though I could wiſh,
You were conduƈted to a gentle Bath,
And Balmes applyed to you, yet dare I neuer
Deny your asking, take your choice of thoſe
That beſt can ayde your aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thoſe are they
That moſt are willing; if any ſuch be heere,
(As it were ſinne to doubt) that loue this painting
Wherein you ſee me ſmear’d, if any feare
Leſſen his perſon, then an ill report:
If any thinke, braue death out-weighes bad life,
And that his Countries deerer then himſelfe,
Let him alone: Or ſo many ſo minded,
Waue thus to expreſſe his diſpoſition,
And follow Martius.
speech.stagedir: They all ſhout and waue their ſwords, take him vp in their Armes, and caſt vp their Caps.
speech.line: Oh me alone, make you a ſword of me:
If theſe ſhewes be not outward, which of you
But is foure Volces? None of you, but is
Able to beare againſt the great Auffidious
A Shield, as hard as his. A certaine number
(Though thankes to all) muſt I ſeleƈt from all:
The reſt ſhall beare the buſineſſe in ſome other fight
(As cauſe will be obey’d:) pleaſe you to March,
And foure ſhall quickly draw out my Command,
Which men are beſt inclin’d.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: March on my Fellowes:
Make good this oſtentation, and you ſhall
Diuide in all, with vs.

scene.stagedir: Titus Lartius, hauing ſet a guard vpon Carioles, going with Drum and Trumpet toward Cominius, and Caius Martius, Enters with a Lieutenant, other Souldiours, and a Scout.

speech.speaker: Lar.
speech.line: So, let the Ports be guarded; keepe your Duties
As I haue ſet them downe. If I do ſend, diſpatch
Thoſe Centuries to our ayd, the reſt will ſerue
For a ſhort holding, if we looſe the Field,
We cannot keepe the Towne.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Feare not our care Sir.

speech.speaker: Lart.
speech.line: Hence; and ſhut your gates vpon’s:
Our Guider come, to th’Roman Campe conduƈt vs.

scene.stagedir: Enter Martius and Auffidius at ſeueral doores.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Ile fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
Worſe then a Promiſe-breaker.

speech.speaker: Auffid.
speech.line: We hate alike:
Not Affricke ownes a Serpent I abhorre
More then thy Fame and Enuy: Fix thy foot.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Let the firſt Budger dye the others Slaue,
And the Gods doome him after.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: If I flye Martius, hollow me like a Hare.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Within theſe three houres Tullus
Alone I fought in your Corioles walles,
And made what worke I pleas’d: ’Tis not my blood,
Wherein thou ſeeſt me maskt, for thy Reuenge
Wrench vp thy power to th’higheſt.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Wer’t thou the Heƈtor,
That was the whip of your bragg’d Progeny,
Thou ſhould’ſt not ſcape me heere.
speech.stagedir: Heere they fight, and certaine Volces come in the ayde of Auffi. Martius fights til they be driuen in breathles.
speech.line: Officious and not valiant, you haue ſham’d me
In your condemned Seconds.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Alarum. A Retreat is ſounded. Enter at one Doore Cominius, with the Romanes: At another Doore Martius, with his Arme in a Scarfe.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: If I ſhould tell thee o’re this thy dayes Worke,
Thou’t not beleeue thy deeds: but Ile report it,
Where Senators ſhall mingle teares with ſmiles,
Where great Patricians ſhall attend, and ſhrug,
I’th’end admire: where Ladies ſhall be frighted,
And gladly quak’d, heare more: where the dull Tribunes,
That with the fuſtie Plebeans, hate thine Honors,
Shall ſay againſt their hearts, We thanke the Gods
Our Rome hath ſuch a Souldier.
Yet cam’ſt thou to a Morſell of this Feaſt,
Hauing fully din’d before.

scene.stagedir: Enter Titus with his Power, from the Purſuit.

speech.speaker: Titus Lartius.
speech.line: Oh Generall:
Here is the Steed, wee the Capariſon:
Hadſt thou beheld—

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: Pray now, no more:
My Mother, who ha’s a Charter to extoll her Bloud,
When ſhe do’s prayſe me, grieues me:
I haue done as you haue done, that’s what I can,
Induc’d as you haue beene, that’s for my Countrey:
He that ha’s but effeƈted his good will,
Hath ouerta’ne mine Aƈt.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: You ſhall not be the Graue of your deſeruing,
Rome muſt know the value of her owne:
’Twere a Concealement worſe then a Theft,
No leſſe then a Traducement,
To hide your doings, and to ſilence that,
Which to the ſpire, and top of prayſes vouch’d,
Would ſeeme but modeſt: therefore I beſeech you,
In ſigne of what you are, not to reward
What you haue done, before our Armie heare me.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: I haue ſome Wounds vpon me, and they ſmart
To heare themſelues remembred.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Should they not:
Well might they feſter ’gainſt Ingratitude,
And tent themſelues with death: of all the Horſes,
Whereof we haue ta’ne good, and good ſtore of all,
The Treaſure in this field atchieued, and Citie,
We render you the Tenth, to be ta’ne forth,
Before the common diſtribution,
At your onely choyſe.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: I thanke you Generall:
But cannot make my heart conſent to take
A Bribe, to pay my Sword: I dœ refuſe it,
And ſtand vpon my common part with thoſe,
That haue beheld the doing.

scene.stagedir: A long flouriſh. They all cry, Martius, Martius, caſt vp their Caps and Launces: Cominius and Lartius ſtand bare.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: May theſe ſame Inſtruments, which you prophane,
Neuer ſound more: when Drums and Trumpets ſhall
I’th’field proue flatterers, let Courts and Cities be
Made all of falſe-fac’d ſoothing:
When Steele growes ſoft, as the Paraſites Silke,
Let him be made an Ouerture for th’Warres:
No more I ſay, for that I haue not waſh’d
My Noſe that bled, or foyl’d ſome debile Wretch,
Which without note, here’s many elſe haue done,
You ſhoot me forth in acclamations hyperbolicall,
As if I lou’d my little ſhould be dieted
In prayſes, ſawc’ſt with Lyes.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Too modeſt are you:
More cruell to your good report, then gratefull
To vs, that giue you truly: by your patience,
If ’gainſt your ſelfe you be incens’d, wee’le put you
(Like one that meanes his proper harme) in Manacles,
Then reaſon ſafely with you: Therefore be it knowne,
As to vs, to all the World, That Caius Martius
Weares this Warres Garland: in token of the which,
My Noble Steed, knowne to the Campe, I giue him,
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioles, call him,
With all th’applauſe and Clamor of the Hoaſt,
Marcus Caius Coriolanus. Beare th’addition Nobly euer?

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: Marcus Caius Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: I will gœ waſh:
And when my Face is faire, you ſhall perceiue
Whether I bluſh or no: howbeit, I thanke you,
I meane to ſtride your Steed, and at all times
To vnder-creſt your good Addition,
To th’faireneſſe of my power.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: So, to our Tent:
Where ere we dœ repoſe vs, we will write
To Rome of our ſucceſſe: you Titus Lartius
Muſt to Corioles backe, ſend vs to Rome
The beſt, with whom we may articulate,
For their owne good, and ours.

speech.speaker: Lartius.
speech.line: I ſhall, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: The Gods begin to mocke me:
I that now refus’d moſt Princely gifts,
Am bound to begge of my Lord Generall.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Tak’t, ’tis yours: what is’t?

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: I ſometime lay here in Corioles,
At a poore mans houſe: he vs’d me kindly,
He cry’d to me: I ſaw him Priſoner:
But then Auffidius was within my view,
And Wrath o’re-whelm’d my pittie: I requeſt you
To giue my poore Hoſt freedome.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Oh well begg’d:
Were he the Butcher of my Sonne, he ſhould
Be free, as is the Winde: deliuer him, Titus.

speech.speaker: Lartius.
speech.line: Martius, his Name.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: By Iupiter forgot:
I am wearie, yea, my memorie is tyr’d:
Haue we no Wine here?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Gœ we to our Tent:
The bloud vpon your Viſage dryes, ’tis time
It ſhould be lookt too: come.

scene.stagedir: A flouriſh. Cornets. Enter Tullus Auffidius bloudie, with two or three Souldiors.

speech.speaker: Auffi.
speech.line: The Towne is ta’ne.

speech.speaker: Sould.
speech.line: ’Twill be deliuer’d backe on good Condition.

speech.speaker: Auffid.
speech.line: Condition?
I would I were a Roman, for I cannot,
Being a Volce, be that I am. Condition?
What good Condition can a Treatie finde
I’th’part that is at mercy? fiue times, Martius,
I haue fought with thee; ſo often haſt thou beat me:
And would’ſt dœ ſo, I thinke, ſhould we encounter
As often as we eate. By th’Elements,
If ere againe I meet him beard to beard,
He’s mine, or I am his: Mine Emulation
Hath not that Honor in’t it had: For where
I thought to cruſh him in an equall Force,
True Sword to Sword: Ile potche at him ſome way,
Or Wrath, or Craft may get him.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: He’s the diuell.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Bolder, though not ſo ſubtle: my valors poiſon’d,
With onely ſuff’ring ſtaine by him: for him
Shall flye out of it ſelfe, nor ſleepe, nor ſanƈtuary,
Being naked, ſicke; nor Phane, nor Capitoll,
The Prayers of Prieſts, nor times of Sacrifice:
Embarquements all of Fury, ſhall lift vp
Their rotten Priuiledge, and Cuſtome ’gainſt
My hate to Martius. Where I finde him, were it
At home, vpon my Brothers Guard, euen there
Againſt the hoſpitable Canon, would I
Waſh my fierce hand in’s heart. Go you to th’Citie,
Learne how ’tis held, and what they are that muſt
Be Hoſtages for Rome.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: Will not you go?

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: I am attended at the Cyprus groue. I pray you
(’Tis South the City Mils) bring me word thither
How the world gœs: that to the pace of it
I may ſpurre on my iourney.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: I ſhall ſir.

scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius with the two Tribunes of the people, Sicinius & Brutus.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: The Agurer tels me, wee ſhall haue Newes to
night.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Good or bad?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Not according to the prayer of the people, for
they loue not Martius.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Nature teaches Beaſts to know their Friends.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Pray you, who dœs the Wolfe loue?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: The Lambe.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I, to deuour him, as the hungry Plebeians would
the Noble Martius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He’s a Lambe indeed, that baes like a Beare.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Hee’s a Beare indeede, that liues like a Lambe.
You two are old men, tell me one thing that I ſhall aske
you.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Well ſir.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: In what enormity is Martius poore in, that you
two haue not in abundance?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He’s poore in no one fault, but ſtor’d withall.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Eſpecially in Pride.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: And topping all others in boaſting.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: This is ſtrange now: Do you two know, how
you are cenſured heere in the City, I mean of vs a’th’right
hand File, do you?

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Why? how are we cenſur’d?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Becauſe you talke of Pride now, will you not
be angry.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Well, well ſir, well.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Why ’tis no great matter: for a very little theefe
of Occaſion, will rob you of a great deale of Patience:
Giue your diſpoſitions the reines, and bee angry at your
pleaſures (at the leaſt) if you take it as a pleaſure to you, in
being ſo: you blame Martius for being proud.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: We do it not alone, ſir.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I know you can dœ very little alone, for your
helpes are many, or elſe your aƈtions would growe won—
drous ſingle: your abilities are to Infant-like, for dooing
much alone. You talke of Pride: Oh, that you could turn
your eyes toward the Napes of your neckes, and make
but an Interiour ſuruey of your good ſelues. Oh that you
could.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: What then ſir?

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Why then you ſhould diſcouer a brace of vn—
meriting, proud, violent, teſtie Magiſtrates (alias Fooles)
as any in Rome.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Menenius, you are knowne well enough too.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: I am knowne to be a humorous Patritian, and
one that loues a cup of hot Wine, with not a drop of alay—
ing Tiber in’t: Said, to be ſomething imperfeƈt in fauou—
ring the firſt complaint, haſty and Tinder-like vppon, to
triuiall motion: One, that conuerſes more with the But—
tocke of the night, then with the forhead of the morning.
What I think, I vtter, and ſpend my malice in my breath.
Meeting two ſuch Weales men as you are (I cannot call
you Licurguſſes,) if the drinke you giue me, touch my Pa—
lat aduerſly, I make a crooked face at it, I can ſay, your
Worſhippes haue deliuer’d the matter well, when I finde
the Aſſe in compound, with the Maior part of your ſylla—
bles. And though I muſt be content to beare with thoſe,
that ſay you are reuerend graue men, yet they lye deadly,
that tell you haue good faces, if you ſee this in the Map
of my Microcoſme, followes it that I am knowne well e—
nough too? What harme can your beeſome Conſpeƈtui—
ties gleane out of this Charraƈter, if I be knowne well e—
nough too.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Come ſir come, we know you well enough.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: You know neither mee, your ſelues, nor any
thing: you are ambitious, for poore knaues cappes and
legges: you weare out a good wholeſome Forenoone, in
hearing a cauſe betweene an Orendge wife, and a Forfet—
seller, and then reiourne the Controuerſie of three-pence
to a ſecond day of Audience. When you are hearing a
matter betweene party and party, if you chaunce to bee
pinch’d with the Collicke, you make faces like Mum—
mers, ſet vp the bloodie Flagge againſt all Patience, and
in roaring for a Chamber-pot, diſmiſſe the Controuerſie
bleeding, the more intangled by your hearing: All the
peace you make in their Cauſe, is calling both the parties
Knaues. You are a payre of ſtrange ones.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Come, come, you are well vnderſtood to bee a
perfeƈter gyber for the Table, then a neceſſary Bencher
in the Capitoll.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Our very Prieſts muſt become Mockers, if they
ſhall encounter ſuch ridiculous Subieƈts as you are, when
you ſpeake beſt vnto the purpoſe. It is not woorth the
wagging of your Beards, and your Beards deſerue not ſo
honourable a graue, as to ſtuffe a Botchers Cuſhion, or to
be intomb’d in an Aſſes Packe-ſaddle; yet you muſt bee
ſaying, Martius is proud: who in a cheape eſtimation, is
worth all your predeceſſors, ſince Deucalion, though per—
aduenture ſome of the beſt of ’em were hereditarie hang—
men. Godden to your Worſhips, more of your conuer—
ſation would infeƈt my Braine, being the Heardſmen of
the Beaſtly Plebeans. I will be bold to take my leaue of
you.

speech.speaker: Bru. and Scic.
speech.line: How now (my as faire as Noble) Ladyes, and the Moone
were ſhee Earthly, no Nobler; whither dœ you follow
your Eyes ſo faſt?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Honorable Menenius, my Boy Martius appro—
ches: for the loue of Iuno let’s gœ.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Ha? Martius comming home?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I, worthy Menenius, and with moſt proſperous
approbation.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Take my Cappe Iupiter, and I thanke thee:
hoo, Martius comming home?

speech.speaker: 2.Ladies.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis true.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Looke, here’s a Letter from him, the State hath
another, his Wife another, and (I thinke) there’s one at
home for you.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: I will make my very houſe reele to night:
A Letter for me?

speech.speaker: Virgil.
speech.line: Yes certaine, there’s a Letter for you, I ſaw’t.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: A Letter for me? it giues me an Eſtate of ſe—
uen yeeres health; in which time, I will make a Lippe at
the Phyſician: The moſt ſoueraigne Preſcription in Galen,
is but Emperickqutique; and to this Preſeruatiue, of no
better report then a Horſe-drench. Is he not wounded?
he was wont to come home wounded?

speech.speaker: Virgil.
speech.line: Oh no, no, no.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Oh, he is wounded, I thanke the Gods for’t.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: So dœ I too, if it be not too much: brings a
Viƈtorie in his Pocket? the wounds become him.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: On’s Browes: Menenius, hee comes the third
time home with the Oaken Garland.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Ha’s he diſciplin’d Auffidius ſoundly?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but
Auffidius got off.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: And ’twas time for him too, Ile warrant him
that: and he had ſtay’d by him, I would not haue been ſo
fiddious’d, for all the Cheſts in Carioles, and the Gold
that’s in them. Is the Senate poſſeſt of this?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Good Ladies let’s gœ. Yes, yes, yes: The
Senate ha’s Letters from the Generall, wherein hee giues
my Sonne the whole Name of the Warre: he hath in this
aƈtion out-done his former deeds doubly.

speech.speaker: Valer.
speech.line: In troth, there’s wondrous things ſpoke of him.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Wondrous: I, I warrant you, and not with—
out his true purchaſing.

speech.speaker: Virgil.
speech.line: The Gods graunt them true.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: True? pow waw.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: True? Ile be ſworne they are true: where is
hee wounded, God ſaue your good Worſhips? Martius
is comming home: hee ha’s more cauſe to be prowd:
where is he wounded?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Ith’Shoulder, and ith’left Arme: there will be
large Cicatrices to ſhew the People, when hee ſhall ſtand
for his place: he receiued in the repulſe of Tarquin ſeuen
hurts ith’Body.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: One ith’Neck, and two ith’Thigh, there’s nine
that I know.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Hee had, before this laſt Expedition, twentie
fiue Wounds vpon him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Now it’s twentie ſeuen; euery gaſh was an
Enemies Graue. Hearke, the Trumpets.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Theſe are the Vſhers of Martius:
Before him, hee carryes Noyſe;
And behinde him, hee leaues Teares:
Death, that darke Spirit, in’s neruie Arme doth lye,
Which being aduanc’d, declines, and then men dye.

scene.stagedir: A Sennet. Trumpets ſound. Enter Cominius the Generall, and Titus Latius: betweene them Coriolanus, crown’d with an Oaken Garland, with Captaines and Souldiers, and a Herauld.

speech.speaker: Herauld.
speech.line: Know Rome, that all alone Martius did fight
Within Corioles Gates: where he hath wonne,
With Fame, a Name to Martius Caius:
Theſe in honor followes Martius Caius Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: No more of this, it dœs offend my heart: pray
now no more.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Looke, Sir, your Mother.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Oh! you haue, I know, petition’d all the Gods
for my proſperitie.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Nay, my good Souldier, vp:
My gentle Martius, worthy Caius,
And by deed-atchieuing Honor newly nam’d,
What is it ( Coriolanus) muſt I call thee?
But oh, thy Wife.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: My gracious ſilence, hayle:
Would’ſt thou haue laugh’d, had I come Coffin’d home,
That weep’ſt to ſee me triumph? Ah my deare,
Such eyes the Widowes in Carioles were,
And Mothers that lacke Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Now the Gods Crowne thee.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: And liue you yet? Oh my ſweet Lady, pardon.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I know not where to turne.
Oh welcome home: and welcome Generall,
And y’are welcome all.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: A hundred thouſand Welcomes:
I could weepe, and I could laugh,
I am light, and heauie; welcome:
A Curſe begin at very root on’s heart,
That is not glad to ſee thee.
You are three, that Rome ſhould dote on:
Yet by the faith of men, we haue
Some old Crab-trees here at home,
That will not be grafted to your Ralliſh.
Yet welcome Warriors:
Wee call a Nettle, but a Nettle;
And the faults of fooles, but folly.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Euer right.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Menenius, euer, euer.

speech.speaker: Herauld.
speech.line: Giue way there, and gœ on.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Your Hand, and yours?
Ere in our owne houſe I dœ ſhade my Head,
The good Patricians muſt be viſited,
From whom I haue receiu’d not onely greetings,
But with them, change of Honors.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I haue liued,
To ſee inherited my very Wiſhes,
And the Buildings of my Fancie:
Onely there’s one thing wanting,
Which (I doubt not) but our Rome
Will caſt vpon thee.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Know, good Mother,
I had rather be their ſeruant in my way,
Then ſway with them in theirs.

speech.speaker: Com
speech.line: On, to the Capitall.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: All tongues ſpeake of him, and the bleared ſights
Are ſpeƈtacled to ſee him. Your pratling Nurſe
Into a rapture lets her Baby crie,
While ſhe chats him: the Kitchin Malkin pinnes
Her richeſt Lockram ’bout her reechie necke,
Clambring the Walls to eye him:
Stalls, Bulkes, Windowes, are ſmother’d vp,
Leades fill’d, and Ridges hors’d
With variable Complexions; all agreeing
In earneſtneſſe to ſee him: ſeld-showne Flamins
Dœ preſſe among the popular Throngs, and puffe
To winne a vulgar ſtation: our veyl’d Dames
Commit the Warre of White and Damaske
In their nicely gawded Cheekes, toth’wanton ſpoyle
Of Phœbus burning Kiſſes: ſuch a poother,
As if that whatſœuer God, who leades him,
Were ſlyly crept into his humane powers,
And gaue him gracefull poſture.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: On the ſuddaine, I warrant him Conſull.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Then our Office may, during his power, gœ
ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: He cannot temp’rately tranſport his Honors,
From where he ſhould begin, and end, but will
Loſe thoſe he hath wonne.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: In that there’s comfort.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: Doubt not,
The Commoners, for whom we ſtand, but they
Vpon their ancient mallice, will forget
With the leaſt cauſe, theſe his new Honors,
Which that he will giue them, make I as little queſtion,
As he is prowd to doo’t.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: I heard him ſweare,
Were he to ſtand for Conſull, neuer would he
Appeare i’th’Market place, nor on him put
The Naples Veſture of Humilitie,
Nor ſhewing (as the manner is) his Wounds
Toth’ People, begge their ſtinking Breaths.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: ’Tis right.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: It was his word:
Oh he would miſſe it, rather then carry it,
But by the ſuite of the Gentry to him,
And the deſire of the Nobles.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: I wiſh no better, then haue him hold that pur—
poſe, and to put it in execution.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: ’Tis moſt like he will.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: It ſhall be to him then, as our good wills; a
ſure destruction.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: So it muſt fall out
To him, or our Authorities, for an end.
We muſt ſuggeſt the People, in what hatred
He ſtill hath held them: that to’s power he would
Haue made them Mules, ſilenc’d their Pleaders,
And diſpropertied their Freedomes; holding them,
In humane Aƈtion, and Capacitie,
Of no more Soule, nor fitneſſe for the World,
Then Cammels in their Warre, who haue their Prouand
Onely for bearing Burthens, and ſore blowes
For ſinking vnder them.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: This (as you ſay) ſuggeſted,
At ſome time, when his ſoaring Inſolence
Shall teach the People, which time ſhall not want,
If he be put vpon’t, and that’s as eaſie,
As to ſet Dogges on Sheepe, will be his fire
To kindle their dry Stubble: and their Blaze
Shall darken him for euer.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: You are ſent for to the Capitoll:
’Tis thought, that Martius ſhall be Conſull:
I haue ſeene the dumbe men throng to ſee him,
And the blind to heare him ſpeak: Matrons flong Gloues,
Ladies and Maids their Scarffes, and Handkerchers,
Vpon him as he paſs’d: the Nobles bended
As to Ioues Statue, and the Commons made
A Shower, and Thunder, with their Caps, and Showts:
I neuer ſaw the like.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Let’s to the Capitoll,
And carry with vs Eares and Eyes for th’time,
But Hearts for the euent.

speech.speaker: Scicin
speech.line: Haue with you.

scene.stagedir: Enter two Officers, to lay Cuſhions, as it were, in the Capitoll.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: Come, come, they are almoſt here: how many
ſtand for Conſulſhips?

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: Three, they ſay: but ’tis thought of euery one,
Coriolanus will carry it.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: That’s a braue fellow: but hee’s vengeance
prowd, and loues not the common people.

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: ’Faith, there hath beene many great men that
haue flatter’d the people, who ne’re loued them; and there
be many that they haue loued, they know not wherefore:
ſo that if they loue they know not why, they hate vpon
no better a ground. Therefore, for Coriolanus neyther to
care whether they loue, or hate him, manifeſts the true
knowledge he ha’s in their diſpoſition, and out of his No—
ble careleſneſſe lets them plainely ſee’t.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: If he did not care whether he had their loue, or
no, hee waued indifferently, ’twixt doing them neyther
good, nor harme: but hee ſeekes their hate with greater
deuotion, then they can render it him; and leaues nothing
vndone, that may fully diſcouer him their oppoſite. Now
to ſeeme to affeƈt the mallice and diſpleaſure of the Peo—
ple, is as bad, as that which he diſlikes, to flatter them for
their loue.

speech.speaker: 2.Off.
speech.line: Hee hath deſerued worthily of his Countrey,
and his aſſent is not by ſuch eaſie degrees as thoſe, who
hauing beene ſupple and courteous to the People, Bon—
netted, without any further deed, to haue them at all into
their eſtimation, and report: but hee hath ſo planted his
Honors in their Eyes, and his aƈtions in their Hearts, that
for their Tongues to be ſilent, and not confeſſe ſo much,
were a kinde of ingratefull Iniurie: to report otherwiſe,
were a Mallice, that giuing it ſelfe the Lye, would plucke
reproofe and rebuke from euery Eare that heard it.

speech.speaker: 1.Off.
speech.line: No more of him, hee’s a worthy man: make
way, they are comming.

scene.stagedir: A Sennet. Enter the Patricians, and the Tribunes of the People, Liƈtors before them: Coriolanus, Menenius, Cominius the Conſul: Scicinius and Brutus take their places by themſelues: Coriolanus ſtands.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Hauing determin’d of the Volces,
And to ſend for Titus Lartius: it remaines,
As the maine Point of this our after-meeting,
To gratifie his Noble ſeruice, that hath
Thus ſtood for his Countrey. Therefore pleaſe you,
Moſt reuerend and graue Elders, to deſire
The preſent Conſull, and laſt Generall,
In our well-found Succeſſes, to report
A little of that worthy Worke, perform’d
By Martius Caius Coriolanus: whom
We met here, both to thanke, and to remember,
With Honors like himſelfe.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Speake, good Cominius:
Leaue nothing out for length, and make vs thinke
Rather our ſtates defeƈtiue for requitall,
Then we to ſtretch it out. Maſters a’th’People,
We dœ requeſt your kindeſt eares: and after
Your louing motion toward the common Body,
To yeeld what paſſes here.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: We are conuented vpon a pleaſing Treatie, and
haue hearts inclinable to honor and aduance the Theame
of our Aſſembly.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Which the rather wee ſhall be bleſt to dœ, if
he remember a kinder value of the People, then he hath
hereto priz’d them at.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: That’s off, that’s off: I would you rather had
been ſilent: Pleaſe you to heare Cominius ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Moſt willingly: but yet my Caution was
more pertinent then the rebuke you giue it.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: He loues your People, but tye him not to be
their Bed-fellow: Worthie Cominius ſpeake.
speech.stagedir: Coriolanus riſes, and offers to gœ away.
speech.line: Nay, keepe your place.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: Sit Coriolanus: neuer ſhame to heare
What you haue Nobly done.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Your Honors pardon:
I had rather haue my Wounds to heale againe,
Then heare ſay how I got them.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Sir, I hope my words dis-bench’d you not?

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: No Sir: yet oft,
When blowes haue made me ſtay, I fled from words.
You ſooth’d not, therefore hurt not: but your People,
I loue them as they weigh—

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Pray now ſit downe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I had rather haue one ſcratch my Head i’th’Sun,
When the Alarum were ſtrucke, then idly ſit
To heare my Nothings monſter’d.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Maſters of the People,
Your multiplying Spawne, how can he flatter?
That’s thouſand to one good one, when you now ſee
He had rather venture all his Limbes for Honor,
Then on ones Eares to heare it. Proceed Cominius.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I ſhall lacke voyce: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be vtter’d feebly: it is held,
That Valour is the chiefeſt Vertue,
And moſt dignifies the hauer: if it be,
The man I ſpeake of, cannot in the World
Be ſingly counter-poys’d. At ſixteene yeeres,
When Tarquin made a Head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the marke of others: our then Diƈtator,
Whom with all prayſe I point at, ſaw him fight,
When with his Amazonian Shinne he droue
The brizled Lippes before him: he beſtrid
An o’re-preſt Roman, and i’th’Conſuls view
Slew three Oppoſers: Tarquins ſelfe he met,
And ſtrucke him on his Knee: in that dayes feates,
When he might aƈt the Woman in the Scene,
He prou’d beſt man i’th’field, and for his meed
Was Brow-bound with the Oake. His Pupill age
Man-entred thus, he waxed like a Sea,
And in the brunt of ſeuenteene Battailes ſince,
He lurcht all Swords of the Garland: for this laſt,
Before, and in Corioles, let me ſay
I cannot ſpeake him home: he ſtopt the flyers,
And by his rare example made the Coward
Turne terror into ſport: as Weeds before
A Veſſell vnder ſayle, ſo men obey’d,
And fell below his Stem: his Sword, Deaths ſtampe,
Where it did marke, it tooke from face to foot:
He was a thing of Blood, whoſe euery motion
Was tim’d with dying Cryes: alone he entred
The mortall Gate of th’Citie, which he painted
With ſhunleſſe deſtinie: aydeleſſe came off,
And with a ſudden re-inforcement ſtrucke
Carioles like a Planet: now all’s his,
When by and by the dinne of Warre gan pierce
His readie ſence: then ſtraight his doubled ſpirit
Requickned what in fleſh was fatigate,
And to the Battaile came he, where he did
Runne reeking o’re the liues of men, as if ’twere
A perpetuall ſpoyle: and till we call’d
Both Field and Citie ours, he neuer ſtood
To eaſe his Breſt with panting.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Worthy man.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: He cannot but with meaſure fit the Honors
which we deuiſe him.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Our ſpoyles he kickt at,
And look’d vpon things precious, as they were
The common Muck of the World: he couets leſſe
Then Miſerie it ſelfe would giue, rewards his deeds
With doing them, and is content
To ſpend the time, to end it.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Hee’s right Noble, let him be call’d for.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: Call Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: He doth appeare.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleas’d to make
thee Conſull.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I dœ owe them ſtill my Life, and Seruices.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: It then remaines, that you dœ ſpeake to the
People.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I dœ beſeech you,
Let me o’re-leape that cuſtome: for I cannot
Put on the Gowne, ſtand naked, and entreat them
For my Wounds ſake, to giue their ſufferage:
Pleaſe you that I may paſſe this doing.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Sir, the People muſt haue their Voyces,
Neyther will they bate one iot of Ceremonie.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Put them not too’t:
Pray you gœ fit you to the Cuſtome,
And take to you, as your Predeceſſors haue,
Your Honor with your forme.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: It is a part that I ſhall bluſh in aƈting,
And might well be taken from the People.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Marke you that.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: To brag vnto them, thus I did, and thus
Shew them th’vnaking Skarres, which I ſhould hide,
As if I had receiu’d them for the hyre
Of their breath onely.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Dœ not ſtand vpon’t:
We recommend to you Tribunes of the People
Our purpoſe to them, and to our Noble Conſull
Wish we all Ioy, and Honor.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: To Coriolanus come all ioy and Honor.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh Cornets. Then Exeunt. Manet Sicinius and Brutus.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You ſee how he intends to vſe the people.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: May they perceiue’s intent: he wil require them
As if he did contemne what he requeſted,
Should be in them to giue.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Come, wee’l informe them
Of our proceedings heere on th’ Market place,
I know they do attend vs.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Once if he do require our voyces, wee ought
not to deny him.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: We may Sir if we will.

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: We haue power in our ſelues to do it, but it is
a power that we haue no power to do: For, if hee ſhew vs
his wounds, and tell vs his deeds, we are to put our ton—
gues into thoſe wounds, and ſpeake for them: So if he tel
vs his Noble deeds, we muſt alſo tell him our Noble ac—
ceptance of them. Ingratitude is monſtrous, and for the
multitude to be ingratefull, were to make a Monſter of
the multitude; of the which, we being members, ſhould
bring our ſelues to be monſtrous members.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: And to make vs no better thought of a little
helpe will ſerue: for once we ſtood vp about the Corne,
he himſelfe ſtucke not to call vs the many-headed Multi—
tude.

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: We haue beene call’d ſo of many, not that our
heads are ſome browne, ſome blacke, ſome Abram, ſome
bald; but that our wits are ſo diuerſly Coulord; and true—
ly I thinke, if all our wittes were to iſſue out of one Scull,
they would flye Eaſt, Weſt, North, South, and their con—
ſent of one direƈt way, ſhould be at once to all the points
a’th Compaſſe.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Thinke you ſo? Which way do you iudge my
wit would flye.

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: Nay your wit will not ſo ſoone out as another
mans will, ’tis ſtrongly wadg’d vp in a blocke-head: but
if it were at liberty, ’twould ſure Southward.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: Why that way?

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: To looſe it ſelfe in a Fogge, where being three
parts melted away with rotten Dewes, the fourth would
returne for Conſcience ſake, to helpe to get thee a Wife.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: You are neuer without your trickes, you may,
you may.

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: Are you all reſolu’d to giue your voyces? But
that’s no matter, the greater part carries it, I ſay. If hee
would incline to the people, there was neuer a worthier
man.
speech.stagedir: Enter Coriolanus in a gowne of Humility, with Menenius.
speech.line: Heere he comes, and in the Gowne of humility, marke
his behauiour: we are not to ſtay altogether, but to come
by him where he ſtands, by ones, by twœs, & by threes.
He’s to make his requeſts by particulars, wherein euerie
one of vs ha’s a ſingle Honor, in giuing him our own voi—
ces with our owne tongues, therefore follow me, and Ile
direƈt you how you ſhall go by him.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Content, content.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Oh Sir, you are not right: haue you not knowne
The worthieſt men haue done’t?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What muſt I ſay, I pray Sir?
Plague vpon’t, I cannot bring
My tognue to ſuch a pace. Looke Sir, my wounds,
I got them in my Countries Seruice, when
Some certaine of your Brethren roar’d, and ranne
From th’noiſe of our owne Drummes.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Oh me the Gods, you muſt not ſpeak of that,
You muſt deſire them to thinke vpon you.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Thinke vpon me? Hang ’em,
I would they would forget me, like the Vertues
Which our Diuines loſe by em.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: You’l marre all,
Ile leaue you: Pray you ſpeake to em, I pray you
In wholſome manner.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Bid them waſh their Faces,
And keepe their teeth cleane: So, heere comes a brace,
You know the cauſe (Sir) of my ſtanding heere.

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: We do Sir, tell vs what hath brought you too’t.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Mine owne deſert.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: Your owne deſert.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I, but mine owne deſire.

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: How not your owne deſire?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: No Sir, ’twas neuer my deſire yet to trouble the
poore with begging.

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: You muſt thinke if we giue you any thing, we
hope to gaine by you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Well then I pray, your price a’th’Conſulſhip.

speech.speaker: 1 Cit.
speech.line: The price is, to aske it kindly.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Kindly ſir, I pray let me ha’t: I haue wounds to
ſhew you, which ſhall bee yours in priuate: your good
voice ſir, what ſay you?

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: You ſhall ha’t worthy Sir.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: A match Sir, there’s in all two worthie voyces
begg’d: I haue your Almes, Adieu.

speech.speaker: 3 Cit.
speech.line: But this is ſomething odde.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: And ’twere to giue againe: but ’tis no matter.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Pray you now, if it may ſtand with the tune
of your voices, that I may bee Conſull, I haue heere the
Cuſtomarie Gowne.
You haue deſerued Nobly of your Countrey, and
you haue not deſerued Nobly.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Your Ænigma.
You haue bin a ſcourge to her enemies, you haue
bin a Rod to her Friends, you haue not indeede loued the
Common people.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: You ſhould account mee the more Vertuous,
that I haue not bin common in my Loue, I will ſir flatter
my ſworne Brother the people to earne a deerer eſtima—
tion of them, ’tis a condition they account gentle: & ſince
the wiſedome of their choice, is rather to haue my Hat,
then my Heart, I will praƈtice the inſinuating nod, and be
off to them moſt counterfetly, that is ſir, I will counter—
fet the bewitchment of ſome popular man, and giue it
bountifull to the deſirers: Therefore beſeech you, I may
be Conſull.
Wee hope to finde you our friend: and therefore
giue you our voices heartily.
You haue receyued many wounds for your Coun—
trey.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: I wil not Seale your knowledge with ſhewing
them. I will make much of your voyces, and ſo trouble
you no farther.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: The Gods giue you ioy Sir heartily.

speech.speaker: Coriol.
speech.line: Moſt ſweet Voyces:
Better it is to dye, better to ſterue,
Then craue the higher, which firſt we do deſerue.
Why in this Wooluiſh tongue ſhould I ſtand heere,
To begge of Hob and Dicke, that dœs appeere
Their needleſſe Vouches: Cuſtome calls me too’t.
What Cuſtome wills in all things, ſhould we doo’t?
The Duſt on antique Time would lye vnſwept,
And mountainous Error be too highly heapt,
For Truth to o’re-peere. Rather then foole it ſo,
Let the high Office and the Honor go
To one that would dœ thus. I am halfe through,
The one part ſuffered, the other will I dœ.
Here come mœ Voyces.
Your Voyces? for your Voyces I haue ſought,
Watcht for your Voyces: for your Voyces, beare
Of Wounds, two dozen odde: Battailes thrice ſix
I haue ſeene, and heard of: for your Voyces,
Haue done many things, ſome leſſe, ſome more:
Your Voyces? Indeed I would be Conſull.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: Hee ha’s done Nobly, and cannot gœ without
any honeſt mans Voyce.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Therefore let him be Conſull: the Gods giue
him ioy, and make him good friend to the People.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Amen, Amen. God ſaue thee, Noble Conſull.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Worthy Voyces.

scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius, with Brutus and Scicinius.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You haue ſtood your Limitation:
And the Tribunes endue you with the Peoples Voyce,
Remaines, that in th’Officiall Markes inueſted,
You anon dœ meet the Senate.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Is this done?

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: The Cuſtome of Requeſt you haue diſcharg’d:
The People dœ admit you, and are ſummon’d
To meet anon, vpon your approbation.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Where? at the Senate-houſe?

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: There, Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: May I change theſe Garments?

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: You may, Sir.

speech.speaker: Cori.
speech.line: That Ile ſtraight do: and knowing my ſelfe again,
Repayre toth’Senate-houſe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile keepe you company. Will you along?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: We ſtay here for the People.

speech.speaker: Scicin
speech.line: Fare you well.
He ha’s it now: and by his Lookes, me thinkes,
’Tis warme at’s heart.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: With a prowd heart he wore his humble Weeds:
Will you diſmiſſe the People?

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: How now, my Maſters, haue you choſe this man?

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: He ha’s our Voyces, Sir.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: We pray the Gods, he may deſerue your loues.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Amen, Sir: to my poore vnworthy notice,
He mock’d vs, when he begg’d our Voyces.

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: Certainely, he flowted vs downe-right.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: No, ’tis his kind of ſpeech, he did not mock vs.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: Not one amongſt vs, ſaue your ſelfe, but ſayes
He vs’d vs ſcornefully: he ſhould haue ſhew’d vs
His Marks of Merit, Wounds receiu’d for’s Countrey.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Why ſo he did, I am ſure.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: No, no: no man ſaw ’em.

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: Hee ſaid hee had Wounds,
Which he could ſhew in priuate:
And with his Hat, thus wauing it in ſcorne,
I would be Conſull, ſayes he: aged Cuſtome,
But by your Voyces, will not ſo permit me.
Your Voyces therefore: when we graunted that,
Here was, I thanke you for your Voyces, thanke you
Your moſt ſweet Voyces: now you haue left your Voyces,
I haue no further with you. Was not this mockerie?

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Why eyther were you ignorant to ſee’t?
Or ſeeing it, of ſuch Childiſh friendlineſſe,
To yeeld your Voyces?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Could you not haue told him,
As you were leſſon’d: When he had no Power,
But was a pettie ſeruant to the State,
He was your Enemie, euer ſpake againſt
Your Liberties, and the Charters that you beare
I’th’ Body of the Weale: and now arriuing
A place of Potencie, and ſway o’th’State,
If he ſhould ſtill malignantly remaine
Faſt Fœ toth’ Plebeij, your Voyces might
Be Curſes to your ſelues. You ſhould haue ſaid,
That as his worthy deeds did clayme no leſſe
Then what he ſtood for: ſo his gracious nature
Would thinke vpon you, for your Voyces,
And tranſlate his Mallice towards you, into Loue,
Standing your friendly Lord.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Thus to haue ſaid,
As you were fore-aduis’d, had toucht his Spirit,
And try’d his Inclination: from him pluckt
Eyther his gracious Promiſe, which you might
As cauſe had call’d you vp, haue held him to;
Or elſe it would haue gall’d his ſurly nature,
Which eaſily endures not Article,
Tying him to ought, ſo putting him to Rage,
You ſhould haue ta’ne th’aduantage of his Choller,
And paſs’d him vneleƈted.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Did you perceiue,
He did ſollicite you in free Contempt,
When he did need your Loues: and dœ you thinke,
That his Contempt ſhall not be bruſing to you,
When he hath power to cruſh? Why, had your Bodyes
No Heart among you? Or had you Tongues, to cry
Againſt the Reƈtorſhip of Iudgement?

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Haue you, ere now, deny’d the asker:
And now againe, of him that did not aske, but mock,
Beſtow your ſu’d-for Tongues?

speech.speaker: 3.Cit.
speech.line: Hee’s not confirm’d, we may deny him yet.

speech.speaker: 2.Cit.
speech.line: And will deny him:
Ile haue fiue hundred Voyces of that ſound.

speech.speaker: 1.Cit.
speech.line: I twice fiue hundred, & their friends, to piece ’em.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Get you hence inſtantly, and tell thoſe friends,
