They haue choſe a Conſull, that will from them take
Their Liberties, make them of no more Voyce
Then Dogges, that are as often beat for barking,
As therefore kept to dœ ſo.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: Let them aſſemble: and on a ſafer Iudgement,
All reuoke your ignorant eleƈtion: Enforce his Pride,
And his old Hate vnto you: beſides, forget not
With what Contempt he wore the humble Weed,
How in his Suit he ſcorn’d you: but your Loues,
Thinking vpon his Seruices, tooke from you
Th’apprehenſion of his preſent portance,
Which moſt gibingly, vngrauely, he did faſhion
After the inueterate Hate he beares you.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Lay a fault on vs, your Tribunes,
That we labour’d (no impediment betweene)
But that you muſt caſt your Eleƈtion on him.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: Say you choſe him, more after our commandment,
Then as guided by your owne true affeƈtions, and that
Your Minds pre-occupy’d with what you rather muſt do,
Then what you ſhould, made you againſt the graine
To Voyce him Conſull. Lay the fault on vs.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: I, ſpare vs not: Say, we read Leƈtures to you,
How youngly he began to ſerue his Countrey,
How long continued, and what ſtock he ſprings of,
The Noble Houſe o’th’ Martians: from whence came
That Ancus Martius, Numaes Daughters Sonne:
Who after great Hoſtilius here was King,
Of the ſame Houſe Publius and Quintus were,
That our beſt Water, brought by Conduits hither,
And Nobly nam’d, ſo twice being Cenſor,
Was his great Anceſtor.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: One thus deſcended,
That hath beſide well in his perſon wrought,
To be ſet high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances: but you haue found,
Skaling his preſent bearing with his paſt,
That hee’s your fixed enemie; and reuoke
Your ſuddaine approbation.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Say you ne’re had don’t,
(Harpe on that ſtill) but by our putting on:
And preſently, when you haue drawne your number,
Repaire toth’ Capitoll.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: We will ſo: almoſt all repent in their eleƈtion.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Let them gœ on:
This Mutinie were better put in hazard,
Then ſtay paſt doubt, for greater:
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
With their refuſall, both obſerue and anſwer
The vantage of his anger.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Toth’Capitoll, come:
We will be there before the ſtreame o’th’People:
And this ſhall ſeeme, as partly ’tis, their owne,
Which we haue goaded on-ward.

scene.stagedir: Cornets. Enter Coriolanus, Menenius, all the Gentry, Cominius, Titus Latius, and other Senators.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Tullus Auffidius then had made new head.

speech.speaker: Latius.
speech.line: He had, my Lord, and that it was which caus’d
Our ſwifter Compoſition.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: So then the Volces ſtand but as at firſt,
Readie when time ſhall prompt them, to make roade
Vpon’s againe.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: They are worne (Lord Conſull) ſo,
That we ſhall hardly in our ages ſee
Their Banners waue againe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Saw you Auffidius?

speech.speaker: Latius.
speech.line: On ſafegard he came to me, and did curſe
Againſt the Volces, for they had ſo vildly
Yeelded the Towne: he is retyred to Antium.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Spoke he of me?

speech.speaker: Latius.
speech.line: He did, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: How? what?

speech.speaker: Latius.
speech.line: How often he had met you Sword to Sword:
That of all things vpon the Earth, he hated
Your perſon moſt: That he would pawne his fortunes
To hopeleſſe reſtitution, ſo he might
Be call’d your Vanquiſher.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: At Antium liues he?

speech.speaker: Latius.
speech.line: At Antium.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I wiſh I had a cauſe to ſeeke him there,
To oppoſe his hatred fully. Welcome home.
Behold, theſe are the Tribunes of the People,
The Tongues o’th’Common Mouth. I do deſpiſe them:
For they dœ pranke them in Authoritie,
Againſt all Noble ſufferance.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Paſſe no further.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Hah? what is that?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: It will be dangerous to gœ on— No further.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What makes this change?

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: The matter?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Hath he not paſs’d the Noble, and the Common?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Cominius, no.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Haue I had Childrens Voyces?

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: Tribunes giue way, he ſhall toth’Market place.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: The People are incens’d againſt him.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: Stop, or all will fall in broyle.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Are theſe your Heard?
Muſt theſe haue Voyces, that can yeeld them now,
And ſtraight diſclaim their toungs? what are your Offices?
You being their Mouthes, why rule you not their Teeth?
Haue you not ſet them on?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Be calme, be calme.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: It is a purpos’d thing, and growes by Plot,
To curbe the will of the Nobilitie:
Suffer’t, and liue with ſuch as cannot rule,
Nor euer will be ruled.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Call’t not a Plot:
The People cry you mockt them: and of late,
When Corne was giuen them gratis, you repin’d,
Scandal’d the Suppliants: for the People, call’d them
Time-pleaſers, flatterers, fœs to Nobleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Why this was knowne before.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Not to them all.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Haue you inform’d them ſithence?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: How? I informe them?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: You are like to dœ ſuch buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Not vnlike each way to better yours.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Why then ſhould I be Conſull? by yond Clouds
Let me deſerue ſo ill as you, and make me
Your fellow Tribune.

speech.speaker: Scicin.
speech.line: You ſhew too much of that,
For which the People ſtirre: if you will paſſe
To where you are bound, you muſt enquire your way,
Which you are out of, with a gentler ſpirit,
Or neuer be ſo Noble as a Conſull,
Nor yoake with him for Tribune.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Let’s be calme.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: The People are abus’d: ſet on, this paltring
Becomes not Rome: nor ha’s Coriolanus
Deſeru’d this ſo diſhonor’d Rub, layd falſely
I’th’plaine Way of his Merit.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Tell me of Corne: this was my ſpeech,
And I will ſpeak’t againe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Not now, not now.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: Not in this heat, Sir, now.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Now as I liue, I will.
My Nobler friends, I craue their pardons:
For the mutable ranke-ſented Meynie,
Let them regard me, as I dœ not flatter,
And therein behold themſelues: I ſay againe,
In ſoothing them, we nouriſh ’gainſt our Senate
The Cockle of Rebellion, Inſolence, Sedition,
Which we our ſelues haue plowed for, ſow’d, & ſcatter’d,
By mingling them with vs, the honor’d Number,
Who lack not Vertue, no, nor Power, but that
Which they haue giuen to Beggers.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Well, no more.

speech.speaker: Senat.
speech.line: No more words, we beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: How? no more?
As for my Country, I haue ſhed my blood,
Not fearing outward force: So ſhall my Lungs
Coine words till their decay, againſt thoſe Meazels
Which we diſdaine ſhould Tetter vs, yet ſought
The very way to catch them.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You ſpeake a’th’people, as if you were a God,
To puniſh; Not a man, of their Infirmity.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: ’Twere well we let the people know’t.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: What, what? His Choller?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Choller? Were I as patient as the midnight ſleep,
By Ioue, ’twould be my minde.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: It is a minde that ſhall remain a poiſon
Where it is: not poyſon any further.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Shall remaine?
Heare you this Triton of the Minnoues? Marke you
His abſolute Shall?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: ’Twas from the Cannon.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Shall? O God! but moſt vnwiſe Patricians: why
You graue, but wreakleſſe Senators, haue you thus
Giuen Hidra heere to chooſe an Officer,
That with his peremptory Shall, being but
The horne, and noiſe o’th’Monſters, wants not ſpirit
To ſay, hee’l turne your Current in a ditch,
And make your Channell his? If he haue power,
Then vale your Ignorance: If none, awake
Your dangerous Lenity: If you are Learn’d,
Be not as common Fooles; if you are not,
Let them haue Cuſhions by you. You are Plebeians,
If they be Senators: and they are no leſſe,
When both your voices blended, the great’ſt taſte
Moſt pallates theirs. They chooſe their Magiſtrate,
And ſuch a one as he, who puts his Shall,
His popular Shall, againſt a grauer Bench
Then euer frown’d in Greece. By Ioue himſelfe,
It makes the Conſuls baſe; and my Soule akes
To know, when two Authorities are vp,
Neither Supreame; How ſoone Confuſion
May enter ’twixt the gap of Both, and take
The one by th’other.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Well, on to’th’Market place.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Who euer gaue that Counſell, to giue forth
The Corne a’th’Store-houſe gratis, as ’twas vs’d
Sometime in Greece.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Well, well, no more of that.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Thogh there the people had more abſolute powre
I ſay they noriſht diſobedience: fed, the ruin of the State.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why ſhall the people giue
One that ſpeakes thus, their voyce?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Ile giue my Reaſons,
More worthier then their Voyces. They know the Corne
Was not our recompence, reſting well aſſur’d
They ne’re did ſeruice for’t; being preſt to’th’Warre,
Euen when the Nauell of the State was touch’d,
They would not thred the Gates: This kinde of Seruice
Did not deſerue Corne gratis. Being i’th’Warre,
There Mutinies and Reuolts, wherein they ſhew’d
Moſt Valour ſpoke not for them. Th’Accuſation
Which they haue often made againſt the Senate,
All cauſe vnborne, could neuer be the Natiue
Of our ſo franke Donation. Well, what then?
How ſhall this Boſome-multiplied, digeſt
The Senates Courteſie? Let deeds expreſſe
What’s like to be their words, We did requeſt it,
We are the greater pole, and in true feare
They gaue vs our demands. Thus we debaſe
The Nature of our Seats, and make the Rabble
Call our Cares, Feares; which will in time
Breake ope the Lockes a’th’Senate, and bring in
The Crowes to pecke the Eagles.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Come enough.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Enough, with ouer meaſure.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: No, take more.
What may be ſworne by, both Diuine and Humane,
Seale what I end withall. This double worſhip,
Whereon part do’s diſdaine with cauſe, the other
Inſult without all reaſon: where Gentry, Title, wiſedom
Cannot conclude, but by the yea and no
Of generall Ignorance, it muſt omit
Reall Neceſſities, and giue way the while
To vnſtable Slightneſſe. Purpoſe ſo barr’d, it followes,
Nothing is done to purpoſe. Therefore beſeech you,
You that will be leſſe fearefull, then diſcreet,
That loue the Fundamentall part of State
More then you doubt the change on’t: That preferre
A Noble life, before a Long, and Wiſh,
To iumpe a Body with a dangerous Phyſicke,
That’s ſure of death without it: at once plucke out
The Multitudinous Tongue, let them not licke
The ſweet which is their poyſon. Your diſhonor
Mangles true iudgement, and bereaues the State
Of that Integrity which ſhould becom’t:
Not hauing the power to do the good it would
For th’ill which doth controul’t.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Has ſaid enough.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Ha’s ſpoken like a Traitor, and ſhall anſwer
As Traitors do.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Thou wretch, deſpight ore-whelme thee:
What ſhould the people do with theſe bald Tribunes?
On whom depending, their obedience failes
To’th’greater Bench, in a Rebellion:
When what’s not meet, but what muſt be, was Law,
Then were they choſen: in a better houre,
Let what is meet, be ſaide it muſt be meet,
And throw their power i’th’duſt.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Manifeſt Treaſon.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: This a Conſull? No.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: The Ediles hœ: Let him be apprehended:

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Go call the people, in whoſe name my Selfe
Attach thee as a Traitorous Innouator:
A Fœ to’th’publike Weale. Obey I charge thee,
And follow to thine anſwer.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Hence old Goat.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Wee’l Surety him.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Ag’d ſir, hands off.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Hence rotten thing, or I ſhall ſhake thy bones
Out of thy Garments.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Helpe ye Citizens.

scene.stagedir: Enter a rabble of Plebeians with the Ædiles.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: On both ſides more reſpeƈt.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Heere’s hee, that would take from you all your
power.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Seize him Ædiles.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Downe with him, downe with him.

speech.speaker: 2 Sen.
speech.line: Weapons, weapons, weapons:
Tribunes, Patricians, Citizens: what ho:
Sicinius, Brutus, Coriolanus, Citizens.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Peace, peace, peace, ſtay, hold, peace.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: What is about to be? I am out of Breath,
Confuſions neere, I cannot ſpeake. You, Tribunes
To’th’people: Coriolanus, patience: Speak good Sicinius.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: Heare me, People peace.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Let’s here our Tribune: peace, ſpeake, ſpeake,
ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: You are at point to loſe your Liberties:
Martius would haue all from you; Martius,
Whom late you haue nam’d for Conſull.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Fie, fie, fie, this is the way to kindle, not to
quench.

speech.speaker: Sena.
speech.line: To vnbuild the Citie, and to lay all flat.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: What is the Citie, but the People?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: True, the People are the Citie.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: By the conſent of all, we were eſtabliſh’d the
Peoples Magiſtrates.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: You ſo remaine.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: And ſo are like to dœ.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: That is the way to lay the Citie flat,
To bring the Roofe to the Foundation,
And burie all, which yet diſtinƈtly raunges
In heapes, and piles of Ruine.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: This deſerues Death.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Or let vs ſtand to our Authoritie,
Or let vs loſe it: we dœ here pronounce,
Vpon the part o’th’People, in whoſe power
We were eleƈted theirs, Martius is worthy
Of preſent Death.

speech.speaker: Scici.
speech.line: Therefore lay hold of him:
Beare him toth’ Rock Tarpeian, and from thence
Into deſtruƈtion caſt him.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Ædiles ſeize him.
All Ple.
Yeeld Martius, yeeld.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Heare me one word, ’beſeech you Tribunes,
heare me but a word.

speech.speaker: Ædiles.
speech.line: Peace, peace.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Be that you ſeeme, truly your Countries friend,
And temp’rately proceed to what you would
Thus violently redreſſe.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Sir, thoſe cold wayes,
That ſeeme like prudent helpes, are very poyſonous,
Where the Diſeaſe is violent. Lay hands vpon him,
And beare him to the Rock.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: No, Ile die here:
There’s ſome among you haue beheld me fighting,
Come trie vpon your ſelues, what you haue ſeene me.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Downe with that Sword, Tribunes withdraw
a while.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Lay hands vpon him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Helpe Martius, helpe: you that be noble, helpe
him young and old.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Downe with him, downe with him.

scene.stagedir: In this Mutinie, the Tribunes, the Ædiles, and the People are beat in.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Gœ, get you to our Houſe: be gone, away.
All will be naught elſe.

speech.speaker: 2.Sena.
speech.line: Get you gone.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Stand faſt, we haue as many friends as enemies.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Shall it be put to that?

speech.speaker: Sena.
speech.line: The Gods forbid:
I prythee noble friend, home to thy Houſe,
Leaue vs to cure this Cauſe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: For ’tis a Sore vpon vs,
You cannot Tent your ſelfe: be gone, ’beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Come Sir, along with vs.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I would they were Barbarians, as they are,
Though in Rome litter’d: not Romans, as they are not,
Though calued i’th’ Porch o’th’ Capitoll:
Be gone, put not your worthy Rage into your Tongue,
One time will owe another.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: On faire ground, I could beat fortie of them.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I could my ſelfe take vp a Brace o’th’ beſt of
them, yea, the two Tribunes.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: But now ’tis oddes beyond Arithmetick,
And Manhood is call’d Foolerie, when it ſtands
Againſt a falling Fabrick. Will you hence,
Before the Tagge returne? whoſe Rage doth rend
Like interrupted Waters, and o’re-beare
What they are vs’d to beare.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Pray you be gone:
Ile trie whether my old Wit be in requeſt
With thoſe that haue but little: this muſt be patcht
With Cloth of any Colour.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Nay, come away.

speech.speaker: Patri.
speech.line: This man ha’s marr’d his fortune.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: His nature is too noble for the World:
He would not flatter Neptune for his Trident,
Or Ioue, for’s power to Thunder: his Heart’s his Mouth:
What his Breſt forges, that his Tongue muſt vent,
And being angry, dœs forget that euer
He heard the Name of Death.
Here’s goodly worke.

speech.speaker: Patri.
speech.line: I would they were a bed.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I would they were in Tyber.
What the vengeance, could he not ſpeake ’em faire?

scene.stagedir: Enter Brutus and Sicinius with the rabble againe.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Where is this Viper,
That would depopulate the city, & be euery man himſelf

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You worthy Tribunes.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: He ſhall be throwne downe the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands: he hath reſiſted Law,
And therefore Law ſhall ſcorne him further Triall
Then the ſeuerity of the publike Power,
Which he ſo ſets at naught.

speech.speaker: 1 Cit.
speech.line: He ſhall well know the Noble Tribunes are
The peoples mouths, and we their hands.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: He ſhall ſure ont.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Sir, ſir.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Peace.

speech.speaker: Me.
speech.line: Do not cry hauocke, where you ſhold but hunt
With modeſt warrant.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Sir, how com’ſt that you haue holpe
To make this reſcue?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Heere me ſpeake? As I do know
The Conſuls worthineſſe, ſo can I name his Faults.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Conſull? what Conſull?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: The Conſull Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He Conſull.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: No, no, no, no, no.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: If by the Tribunes leaue,
And yours good people,
I may be heard, I would craue a word or two,
The which ſhall turne you to no further harme,
Then ſo much loſſe of time.

speech.speaker: Sic.
speech.line: Speake breefely then,
For we are peremptory to diſpatch
This Viporous Traitor: to eieƈt him hence
Were but one danger, and to keepe him heere
Our certaine death: therefore it is decreed,
He dyes to night.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Now the good Gods forbid,
That our renowned Rome, whoſe gratitude
Towards her deſerued Children, is enroll’d
In Ioues owne Booke, like an vnnaturall Dam
Should now eate vp her owne.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: He’s a Diſeaſe that muſt be cut away.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Oh he’s a Limbe, that ha’s but a Diſeaſe
Mortall, to cut it off: to cure it, eaſie.
What ha’s he done to Rome, that’s worthy death?
Killing our Enemies, the blood he hath loſt
(Which I dare vouch, is more then that he hath
By many an Ounce) he dropp’d it for his Country:
And what is left, to looſe it by his Countrey,
Were to vs all that doo’t, and ſuffer it
A brand to th’end a’th World.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: This is cleane kamme.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Meerely awry:
When he did loue his Country, it honour’d him.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: The ſeruice of the foote
Being once gangren’d, is not then reſpeƈted
For what before it was.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Wee’l heare no more:
Purſue him to his houſe, and plucke him thence,
Leaſt his infeƈtion being of catching nature,
Spred further.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: One word more, one word:
This Tiger-footed-rage, when it ſhall find
The harme of vnskan’d ſwiftneſſe, will (too late)
Tye Leaden pounds too’s heeles. Proceed by Proceſſe,
Leaſt parties (as he is belou’d) breake out,
And ſacke great Rome with Romanes.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: If it were ſo?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: What do ye talke?
Haue we not had a taſte of his Obedience?
Our Ediles ſmot: our ſelues reſiſted: come.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Conſider this: He ha’s bin bred i’th’Warres
Since a could draw a Sword, and is ill-school’d
In boulted Language: Meale and Bran together
He throwes without diſtinƈtion. Giue me leaue,
Ile go to him, and vndertake to bring him in peace,
Where he ſhall anſwer by a lawfull Forme
(In peace) to his vtmoſt perill.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Noble Tribunes,
It is the humane way: the other courſe
Will proue to bloody: and the end of it,
Vnknowne to the Beginning.

speech.speaker: Sic.
speech.line: Noble Menenius, be you then as the peoples officer:
Maſters, lay downe your Weapons.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Go not home.

speech.speaker: Sic.
speech.line: Meet on the Market place: wee’l attend you there:
Where if you bring not Martius, wee’l proceede
In our firſt way.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Ile bring him to you.
Let me deſire your company: he muſt come,
Or what is worſt will follow.

speech.speaker: Sena
speech.line: Pray you let’s to him.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Let them pull all about mine eares, preſent me
Death on the Wheele, or at wilde Horſes heeles,
Or pile ten hilles on the Tarpeian Rocke,
That the precipitation might downe ſtretch
Below the beame of ſight; yet will I ſtill
Be thus to them.

speech.speaker: Noble.
speech.line: You do the Nobler.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I muſe my Mother
Do’s not approue me further, who was wont
To call them Wollen Vaſſailes, things created
To buy and ſell with Groats, to ſhew bare heads
In Congregations, to yawne, be ſtill, and wonder,
When one but of my ordinance ſtood vp
To ſpeake of Peace, or Warre. I talke of you,
Why did you wiſh me milder? Would you haue me
Falſe to my Nature? Rather ſay, I play
The man I am.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Oh ſir, ſir, ſir,
I would haue had you put your power well on
Before you had worne it out.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Let go.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: You might haue beene enough the man you are,
With ſtriuing leſſe to be ſo: Leſſer had bin
The things of your diſpoſitions, if
You had not ſhew’d them how ye were diſpos’d
Ere they lack’d power to croſſe you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Let them hang.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I, and burne too.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Come, come, you haue bin too rough, ſomthing
too rough: you muſt returne, and mend it.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: There’s no remedy,
Vnleſſe by not ſo doing, our good Citie
Cleaue in the midd’ſt, and periſh.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Pray be counſail’d;
I haue a heart as little apt as yours,
But yet a braine, that leades my vſe of Anger
To better vantage.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Well ſaid, Noble woman:
Before he ſhould thus ſtoope to’th’heart, but that
The violent fit a’th’time craues it as Phyſicke
For the whole State; I would put mine Armour on,
Which I can ſcarſely beare.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What muſt I do?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Returne to th’Tribunes.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Well, what then? what then?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Repent, what you haue ſpoke.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: For them, I cannot do it to the Gods,
Muſt I then doo’t to them?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: You are too abſolute,
Though therein you can neuer be too Noble,
But when extremities ſpeake. I haue heard you ſay,
Honor and Policy, like vnſeuer’d Friends,
I’th’Warre do grow together: Grant that, and tell me
In Peace, what each of them by th’other looſe,
That they combine not there?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Tuſh, tuſh.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: A good demand.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: If it be Honor in your Warres, to ſeeme
The ſame you are not, which for your beſt ends
You adopt your policy: How is it leſſe or worſe
That it ſhall hold Companionſhip in Peace
With Honour, as in Warre; ſince that to both
It ſtands in like requeſt.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Why force you this?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Becauſe, that
Now it lyes you on to ſpeake to th’people:
Not by your owne inſtruƈtion, nor by’th’matter
Which your heart prompts you, but with ſuch words
That are but roated in your Tongue;
Though but Baſtards, and Syllables
Of no allowance, to your boſomes truth.
Now, this no more diſhonors you at all,
Then to take in a Towne with gentle words,
Which elſe would put you to your fortune, and
The hazard of much blood.
I would diſſemble with my Nature, where
My Fortunes and my Friends at ſtake, requir’d
I ſhould do ſo in Honor. I am in this
Your Wife, your Sonne: Theſe Senators, the Nobles,
And you, will rather ſhew our generall Lowts,
How you can frowne, then ſpend a fawne vpon ’em,
For the inheritance of their loues, and ſafegard
Of what that want might ruine.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Noble Lady,
Come gœ with vs, ſpeake faire: you may ſalue ſo,
Not what is dangerous preſent, but the loſſe
Of what is paſt.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I prythee now, my Sonne,
Gœ to them, with this Bonnet in thy hand,
And thus farre hauing ſtretcht it (here be with them)
Thy Knee buſſing the ſtones: for in ſuch buſineſſe
Aƈtion is eloquence, and the eyes of th’ignorant
More learned then the eares, wauing thy head,
Which often thus correƈting thy ſtout heart,
Now humble as the ripeſt Mulberry,
That will not hold the handling: or ſay to them,
Thou art their Souldier, and being bred in broyles,
Haſt not the ſoft way, which thou do’ſt confeſſe
Were fit for thee to vſe, as they to clayme,
In asking their good loues, but thou wilt frame
Thy ſelfe (forſooth) hereafter theirs ſo farre,
As thou haſt power and perſon.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: This but done,
Euen as ſhe ſpeakes, why their hearts were yours:
For they haue Pardons, being ask’d, as free,
As words to little purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Prythee now,
Gœ, and be rul’d: although I know thou hadſt rather
Follow thine Enemie in a fierie Gulfe,
Then flatter him in a Bower.
Here is Cominius.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I haue beene i’th’ Market place: and Sir ’tis fit
You make ſtrong partie, or defend your ſelfe
By calmeneſſe, or by abſence: all’s in anger.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Onely faire ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I thinke ’twill ſerue, if he can thereto frame his
ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: He muſt, and will:
Prythee now ſay you will, and gœ about it.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Muſt I gœ ſhew them my vnbarb’d Sconce?
Muſt I with my baſe Tongue giue to my Noble Heart
A Lye, that it muſt beare well? I will doo’t:
Yet were there but this ſingle Plot, to looſe
This Mould of Martius, they to duſt ſhould grinde it,
And throw’t againſt the Winde. Toth’ Market place:
You haue put me now to ſuch a part, which neuer
I ſhall diſcharge toth’ Life.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Come, come, wee’le prompt you.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I prythee now ſweet Son, as thou haſt ſaid
My praiſes made thee firſt a Souldier; ſo
To haue my praiſe for this, performe a part
Thou haſt not done before.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Well, I muſt doo’t:
Away my diſpoſition, and poſſeſſe me
Some Harlots ſpirit: My throat of Warre be turn’d,
Which quier’d with my Drumme into a Pipe,
Small as an Eunuch, or the Virgin voyce
That Babies lull a-ſleepe: The ſmiles of Knaues
Tent in my cheekes, and Schoole-boyes Teares take vp
The Glaſſes of my ſight: A Beggars Tongue
Make motion through my Lips, and my Arm’d knees
Who bow’d but in my Stirrop, bend like his
That hath receiu’d an Almes. I will not doo’t,
Leaſt I ſurceaſe to honor mine owne truth,
And by my Bodies aƈtion, teach my Minde
A moſt inherent Baſeneſſe.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: At thy choice then:
To begge of thee, it is my more diſ-honor,
Then thou of them. Come all to ruine, let
Thy Mother rather feele thy Pride, then feare
Thy dangerous Stoutneſſe: for I mocke at death
With as bigge heart as thou. Do as thou liſt,
Thy Valiantneſſe was mine, thou ſuck’ſt it from me:
But owe thy Pride thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Pray be content:
Mother, I am going to the Market place:
Chide me no more. Ile Mountebanke their Loues,
Cogge their Hearts from them, and come home belou’d
Of all the Trades in Rome. Looke, I am going:
Commend me to my Wife, Ile returne Conſull,
Or neuer truſt to what my Tongue can do
I’th way of Flattery further.

speech.speaker: Volum
speech.line: Do your will.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Away, the Tribunes do attend you: arm your ſelf
To anſwer mildely: for they are prepar’d
With Accuſations, as I heare more ſtrong
Then are vpon you yet.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: The word is, Mildely. Pray you let vs go,
Let them accuſe me by inuention: I
Will anſwer in mine Honor.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: I, but mildely.

speech.speaker: Corio
speech.line: Well mildely be it then, Mildely.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: In this point charge him home, that he affeƈts
Tyrannicall power: If he euade vs there,
Inforce him with his enuy to the people,
And that the Spoile got on the Antiats
Was ne’re diſtributed. What, will he come?

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: Hee’s comming.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: How accompanied?

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: With old Menenius, and thoſe Senators
That alwayes fauour’d him.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Haue you a Catalogue
Of all the Voices that we haue procur’d, ſet downe by’th Pole?

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: I haue: ’tis ready.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Haue you colleƈted them by Tribes?

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: I haue.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Aſſemble preſently the people hither:
And when they heare me ſay, it ſhall be ſo,
I’th’right and ſtrength a’th’Commons: be it either
For death, for fine, or Baniſhment, then let them
If I ſay Fine, cry Fine; if Death, cry Death,
Inſiſting on the olde prerogatiue
And power i’th Truth a’th Cauſe.

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: I ſhall informe them.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: And when ſuch time they haue begun to cry,
Let them not ceaſe, but with a dinne confus’d
Inforce the preſent Execution
Of what we chance to Sentence.

speech.speaker: Edi.
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Make them be ſtrong, and ready for this hint
When we ſhall hap to giu’t them.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Go about it,
Put him to Choller ſtraite, he hath bene vs’d
Euer to conquer, and to haue his worth
Of contradiƈtion. Being once chaft, he cannot
Be rein’d againe to Temperance, then he ſpeakes
What’s in his heart, and that is there which lookes
With vs to breake his necke.

scene.stagedir: Enter Coriolanus, Menenius, and Cominius, with others.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Well, heere he comes.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Calmely, I do beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I, as an Hoſtler, that fourth pooreſt peece
Will beare the Knaue by’th Volume:
Th’honor’d Goddes
Keepe Rome in ſafety, and the Chaires of Iuſtice
Supplied with worthy men, plant loue amongs
Through our large Temples with ý ſhewes of peace
And not our ſtreets with Warre.

speech.speaker: 1 Sen.
speech.line: Amen, Amen.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: A Noble wiſh.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Edile with the Plebeians.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Draw neere ye people.

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: Liſt to your Tribunes. Audience:
Peace I ſay.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Firſt heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Both Tri.
speech.line: Well, ſay: Peace hœ.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Shall I be charg’d no further then this preſent?
Muſt all determine heere?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: I do demand,
If you ſubmit you to the peoples voices,
Allow their Officers, and are content
To ſuffer lawfull Cenſure for ſuch faults
As ſhall be prou’d vpon you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I am Content.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Lo Citizens, he ſayes he is Content.
The warlike Seruice he ha’s done, conſider: Thinke
Vpon the wounds his body beares, which ſhew
Like Graues i’th holy Church-yard.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Scratches with Briars, ſcarres to moue
Laughter onely.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Conſider further:
That when he ſpeakes not like a Citizen,
You finde him like a Soldier: do not take
His rougher Aƈtions for malicious ſounds:
But as I ſay, ſuch as become a Soldier,
Rather then enuy you.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Well, well, no more.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What is the matter,
That being paſt for Conſull with full voyce:
I am ſo diſhonour’d, that the very houre
You take it off againe.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Anſwer to vs.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Say then: ’tis true, I ought ſo

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: We charge you, that you haue contriu’d to take
From Rome all ſeaſon’d Office, and to winde
Your ſelfe into a power tyrannicall,
For which you are a Traitor to the people.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: How? Traytor?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Nay temperately: your promiſe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: The fires i’th’loweſt hell. Fould in the people:
Call me their Traitor, thou iniurious Tribune.
Within thine eyes ſate twenty thouſand deaths
In thy hands clutcht: as many Millions in
Thy lying tongue, both numbers. I would ſay
Thou lyeſt vnto thee, with a voice as free,
As I do pray the Gods.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Marke you this people?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: To’th’Rocke, to’th’Rocke with him.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Peace:
We neede not put new matter to his charge:
What you haue ſeene him do, and heard him ſpeake:
Beating your Officers, curſing your ſelues,
Oppoſing Lawes with ſtroakes, and heere defying
Thoſe whoſe great power muſt try him.
Euen this ſo criminall, and in ſuch capitall kinde
Deſerues th’extreameſt death.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: But ſince he hath ſeru’d well for Rome.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What do you prate of Seruice.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: I talke of that, that know it.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: You?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Is this the promiſe that you made your mother.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Know, I pray you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Ile know no further:
Let them pronounce the ſteepe Tarpeian death,
Vagabond exile, Fleaing, pent to linger
But with a graine a day, I would not buy
Their mercie, at the price of one faire word,
Nor checke my Courage for what they can giue,
To haue’t with ſaying, Good morrow.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: For that he ha’s
(As much as in him lies) from time to time
Enui’d againſt the people; ſeeking meanes
To plucke away their power: as now at laſt,
Giuen Hoſtile ſtrokes, and that not in the preſence
Of dreaded Iuſtice, but on the Miniſters
That doth diſtribute it. In the name a’th’people,
And in the power of vs the Tribunes, wee
(Eu’n from this inſtant) baniſh him our Citie
In perill of precipitation
From off the Rocke Tarpeian, neuer more
To enter our Rome gates. I’th’Peoples name,
I ſay it ſhall bee ſo.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo, it ſhall be ſo: let him away:
Hee’s baniſh’d, and it ſhall be ſo.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Heare me my Maſters, and my common friends.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: He’s ſentenc’d: No more hearing.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Let me ſpeake:
I haue bene Conſull, and can ſhew from Rome
Her Enemies markes vpon me. I do loue
My Countries good, with a reſpeƈt more tender,
More holy, and profound, then mine owne life,
My deere Wiues eſtimate, her wombes encreaſe,
And treaſure of my Loynes: then if I would
Speake that.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: We know your drift. Speake what?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: There’s no more to be ſaid, but he is baniſh’d
As Enemy to the people, and his Countrey.
It ſhall bee ſo.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo, it ſhall be ſo.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: You common cry of Curs, whoſe breath I hate,
As reeke a’th’rotten Fennes: whoſe Loues I prize,
As the dead Carkaſſes of vnburied men,
That do corrupt my Ayre: I baniſh you,
And heere remaine with your vncertaintie.
Let euery feeble Rumor ſhake your hearts:
Your Enemies, with nodding of their Plumes
Fan you into diſpaire: Haue the power ſtill
To baniſh your Defenders, till at length
Your ignorance (which findes not till it feeles,
Making but reſeruation of your ſelues,
Still your owne Fœs) deliuer you
As moſt abated Captiues, to ſome Nation
That wonne you without blowes, deſpiſing
For you the City. Thus I turne my backe;
There is a world elſewhere.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Coriolanus, Cominius, with Cumalijs. They all ſhout, and throw vp their Caps.

speech.speaker: Edile.
speech.line: The peoples Enemy is gone, is gone.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Our enemy is baniſh’d, he is gone: Hoo, oo.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Go ſee him out at Gates, and follow him
As he hath follow’d you, with all deſpight
Giue him deſeru’d vexation. Let a guard
Attend vs through the City.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Come, come, lets ſee him out at gates, come:
The Gods preſerue our Noble Tribunes, come.

scene.stagedir: Enter Coriolanus, Volumnia, Virgilia, Menenius, Cominius, with the yong Nobility of Rome.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Come leaue your teares: a brief farwel: the beaſt
With many heads butts me away. Nay Mother,
Where is your ancient Courage? You were vs’d
To ſay, Extreamities was the trier of ſpirits,
That common chances. Common men could beare,
That when the Sea was calme, all Boats alike
Shew’d Maſterſhip in floating. Fortunes blowes,
When moſt ſtrooke home, being gentle wounded, craues
A Noble cunning. You were vs’d to load me
With Precepts that would make inuincible
The heart that conn’d them.

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: Oh heauens! O heauens!

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Nay, I prythee woman.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Now the Red Peſtilence ſtrike al Trades in Rome,
And Occupations periſh.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: What, what, what:
I ſhall be lou’d when I am lack’d. Nay Mother,
Reſume that Spirit, when you were wont to ſay,
If you had beene the Wife of Hercules,
Six of his Labours youl’d haue done, and ſau’d
Your Husband ſo much ſwet. Cominius,
Droope not, Adieu: Farewell my Wife, my Mother,
Ile do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy teares are ſalter then a yonger mans,
And venomous to thine eyes. My (ſometime) Generall,
I haue ſeene the Sterne, and thou haſt oft beheld
Heart-hardning ſpeƈtacles. Tell theſe ſad women,
’Tis fond to waile ineuitable ſtrokes,
As ’tis to laugh at ’em. My Mother, you wot well
My hazards ſtill haue beene your ſolace, and
Beleeu’t not lightly, though I go alone
Like to a lonely Dragon, that his Fenne
Makes fear’d, and talk’d of more then ſeene: your Sonne
Will or exceed the Common, or be caught
With cautelous baits and praƈtice.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: My firſt ſonne,
Whether will thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: Determine on ſome courſe
More then a wilde expoſture, to each chance
That ſtarts i’th’way before thee.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: O the Gods!

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Ile follow thee a Moneth, deuiſe with thee
Where thou ſhalt reſt, that thou may’ſt heare of vs,
And we of thee. So if the time thruſt forth
A cauſe for thy Repeale, we ſhall not ſend
O’re the vaſt world, to ſeeke a ſingle man,
And looſe aduantage, which doth euer coole
Ith’abſence of the needer.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Fare ye well:
Thou haſt yeares vpon thee, and thou art too full
Of the warres ſurfets, to go roue with one
That’s yet vnbruis’d: bring me but out at gate.
Come my ſweet wife, my deereſt Mother, and
My Friends of Noble touch: when I am forth,
Bid me farewell, and ſmile. I pray you come:
While I remaine aboue the ground, you ſhall
Heare from me ſtill, and neuer of me ought
But what is like me formerly.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: That’s worthily
As any eare can heare. Come, let’s not weepe,
If I could ſhake off but one ſeuen yeeres
From theſe old armes and legges, by the good Gods
I’ld with thee, euery foot.

speech.speaker: Corio
speech.line: Giue me thy hand, come.

scene.stagedir: Enter the two Tribunes, Sicinius, and Brutus, with the Edile.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Bid them all home, he’s gone: & wee’l no further,
The Nobility are vexed, whom we ſee haue ſided
In his behalfe.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Now we haue ſhewne our power,
Let vs ſeeme humbler after it is done,
Then when it was a dooing.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Bid them home: ſay their great enemy is gone,
And they, ſtand in their ancient ſtrength.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Diſmiſſe them home. Here comes his Mother.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Let’s not meet her.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: They ſay ſhe’s mad.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: They haue tane note of vs: keepe on your way.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Oh y’are well met:
Th’hoorded plague a’th’Gods requit your loue.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Peace, peace, be not ſo loud.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: If that I could for weeping, you ſhould heare,
Nay, and you ſhall heare ſome. Will you be gone?

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: You ſhall ſtay too: I would I had the power
To ſay ſo to my Husband.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Are you mankinde?

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I foole, is that a ſhame. Note but this Foole,
Was not a man my Father? Had’ſt thou Foxſhip
To baniſh him that ſtrooke more blowes for Rome
Then thou haſt ſpoken words.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Oh bleſſed Heauens!

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Mœ Noble blowes, then euer ӳ wiſe words.
And for Romes good, Ile tell thee what: yet gœ:
Nay but thou ſhalt ſtay too: I would my Sonne
Were in Arabia, and thy Tribe before him,
His good Sword in his hand.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Virg.
speech.line: When then? Hee’ld make an end of thy poſterity

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Baſtards, and all.
Good man, the Wounds that he dœs beare for Rome!

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Come, come, peace.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: I would he had continued to his Country
As he began, and not vnknit himſelfe
The Noble knot he made.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I would he had.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: I would he had? ’Twas thou incenſt the rable.
Cats, that can iudge as fitly of his worth,
As I can of thoſe Myſteries which heauen
Will not haue earth to know.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Pray let’s go.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Now pray ſir get you gone.
You haue done a braue deede: Ere you go, heare this:
As farre as doth the Capitoll exceede
The meaneſt houſe in Rome; ſo farre my Sonne
This Ladies Husband heere; this (do you ſee)
Whom you haue baniſh’d, dœs exceed you all.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Well, well, wee’l leaue you.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Why ſtay we to be baited
With one that wants her Wits.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Take my Prayers with you.
I would the Gods had nothing elſe to do,
But to confirme my Curſſes. Could I meete ’em
But once a day, it would vnclogge my heart
Of what lyes heauy too’t.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You haue told them home,
And by my troth you haue cauſe: you’l Sup with me.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Angers my Meate: I ſuppe vpon my ſelfe,
And ſo ſhall ſterue with Feeding: come, let’s go,
Leaue this faint-puling, and lament as I do,
In Anger, Iuno-like: Come, come, come.

speech.speaker: Mene
speech.line: Fie, fie, fie.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Roman, and a Volce.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I know you well ſir, and you know mee: your
name I thinke is Adrian.

speech.speaker: Volce.
speech.line: It is ſo ſir, truly I haue forgot you.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I am a Roman, and my Seruices are as you are,
againſt ’em. Know you me yet.

speech.speaker: Volce.
speech.line: Nicanor: no.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: The ſame ſir.

speech.speaker: Volce.
speech.line: You had more Beard when I laſt ſaw you, but
your Fauour is well appear’d by your Tongue. What’s
the Newes in Rome: I haue a Note from the Volcean
ſtate to finde you out there. You haue well ſaued mee a
dayes iourney.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: There hath beene in Rome ſtraunge Inſurreƈti—
ons: The people, againſt the Senatours, Patricians, and
Nobles.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Hath bin; is it ended then? Our State thinks not
ſo, they are in a moſt warlike preparation, & hope to com
vpon them, in the heate of their diuiſion

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: The maine blaze of it is paſt, but a ſmall thing
would make it flame againe. For the Nobles receyue ſo
to heart, the Baniſhment of that worthy Coriolanus, that
they are in a ripe aptneſſe, to take al power from the peo—
ple, and to plucke from them their Tribunes for euer.
This lyes glowing I can tell you, and is almoſt mature for
the violent breaking out.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: Coriolanus Baniſht?

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: Baniſh’d ſir.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: You will be welcome with this intelligence Ni-
canor.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: The day ſerues well for them now. I haue heard
it ſaide, the fitteſt time to corrupt a mans Wife, is when
ſhee’s falne out with her Husband. Your Noble Tullus
Auffidius will appeare well in theſe Warres, his great
Oppoſer Coriolanus being now in no requeſt of his coun—
trey.

speech.speaker: Volce.
speech.line: He cannot chooſe: I am moſt fortunate, thus
accidentally to encounter you. You haue ended my Bu—
ſineſſe, and I will merrily accompany you home.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I ſhall betweene this and Supper, tell you moſt
ſtrange things from Rome: all tending to the good of
their Aduerſaries. Haue you an Army ready ſay you?

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: A moſt Royall one: The Centurions, and their
charges diſtinƈtly billetted already in th’entertainment,
and to be on foot at an houres warning.

speech.speaker: Rom.
speech.line: I am ioyfull to heare of their readineſſe, and am
the man I thinke, that ſhall ſet them in preſent Aƈtion. So
ſir, heartily well met, and moſt glad of your Company.

speech.speaker: Volce.
speech.line: You take my part from me ſir, I haue the moſt
cauſe to be glad of yours.

speech.speaker: Rom
speech.line: Well, let vs go together.

scene.stagedir: Enter Coriolanus in meane Apparrell, diſguiſd, and muffled.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: A goodly City is this Antium. Citty,
’Tis I that made thy Widdowes: Many an heyre
Of theſe faire Edifices fore my Warres
Haue I heard groane, and drop: Then know me not,
Leaſt that thy Wiues with Spits, and Boyes with ſtones
In puny Battell ſlay me. Saue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Cit.
speech.line: And you.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Direƈt me, if it be your will, where great Auf-
fidius lies: Is he in Antium?

speech.speaker: Cit.
speech.line: He is, and Feaſts the Nobles of the State, at his
houſe this night.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Which is his houſe, beſeech you?

speech.speaker: Cit.
speech.line: This heere before you.

speech.speaker: Corio
speech.line: Thanke you ſir, farewell.
Oh World, thy ſlippery turnes! Friends now faſt ſworn,
Whoſe double boſomes ſeemes to weare one heart,
Whoſe Houres, whoſe Bed, whoſe Meale and Exerciſe
Are ſtill together: who Twin (as ’twere) in Loue,
Vnſeparable, ſhall within this houre,
On a diſſention of a Doit, breake out
To bittereſt Enmity: So felleſt Fœs,
Whoſe Paſſions, and whoſe Plots haue broke their ſleep
To take the one the other, by ſome chance,
Some tricke not worth an Egge, ſhall grow deere friends
And inter-ioyne their yſſues. So with me,
My Birth-place haue I, and my loues vpon
This Enemie Towne: Ile enter, if he ſlay me
He dœs faire Iuſtice: if he giue me way,
Ile do his Country Seruice.

speech.speaker: 1 Ser.
speech.line: Wine, Wine, Wine: What ſeruice is heere? I
thinke our Fellowes are aſleepe.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Where’s Cotus: my M. cals for him: Cotus.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: A goodly Houſe:
The Feaſt ſmels well: but I appeare not like a Gueſt.

speech.speaker: 1 Ser.
speech.line: What would you haue Friend? whence are you?
Here’s no place for you: pray go to the doore?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I haue deſeru’d no better entertainment, in be—
ing Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Whence are you ſir? Ha’s the Porter his eyes in
his head, that he giues entrance to ſuch Companions?
Pray get you out.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Away.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Away? Get you away.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Now th’art troubleſome.

speech.speaker: 2 Ser.
speech.line: Are you ſo braue: Ile haue you talkt with anon
What Fellowes this?
A ſtrange one as euer I look’d on: I cannot get him
out o’th’houſe: Prythee call my Maſter to him.
What haue you to do here fellow? Pray you auoid
the houſe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Let me but ſtand, I will not hurt your Harth.
What are you?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: A Gentleman.
A maru’llous poore one.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: True, ſo I am.
Pray you poore Gentleman, take vp ſome other ſta—
tion: Heere’s no place for you, pray you auoid: Come.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Follow your Funƈtion, go, and batten on colde
bits.
What you will not? Prythee tell my Maiſter what
a ſtrange Gueſt he ha’s heere.
And I ſhall.
Where dwel’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Vnder the Canopy.
Vnder the Canopy?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I.
Where’s that?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I’th City of Kites and crowes.
I’th City of Kites and Crowes? What an Aſſe it is,
then thou dwel’ſt with Dawes too?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: No, I ſerue not thy Maſter.
How ſir? Do you meddle with my Maſter?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: I, tis an honeſter ſeruice, then to meddle with
thy Miſtris: Thou prat’ſt, and prat’ſt, ſerue with thy tren—
cher: Hence.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Where is this Fellow?
Here ſir, I’de haue beaten him like a dogge, but for
diſturbing the Lords within.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Whence com’ſt thou? What woldſt ӳ? Thy name?
Why ſpeak’ſt not? Speake man: What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: If Tullus not yet thou know’ſt me, and ſeeing
me, doſt not thinke me for the man I am, neceſſitie com—
mands me name my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: What is thy name?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: A name vnmuſicall to the Volcians eares,
And harſh in ſound to thine.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Say, what’s thy name?
Thou haſt a Grim apparance, and thy Face
Beares a Command in’t: Though thy Tackles torne,
Thou ſhew’ſt a Noble Veſſell: What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: Prepare thy brow to frowne: knowſt ӳ me yet?

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: I know thee not? Thy Name:

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: My name is Caius Martius, who hath done
To thee particularly, and to all the Volces
Great hurt and Miſchiefe: thereto witneſſe may
My Surname Coriolanus. The painfull Seruice,
The extreme Dangers, and the droppes of Blood
Shed for my thankleſſe Country, are requitted:
But with that Surname, a good memorie
And witneſſe of the Malice and Diſpleaſure
Which thou ſhould’ſt beare me, only that name remains.
The Cruelty and Enuy of the people,
Permitted by our daſtard Nobles, who
Haue all forſooke me, hath deuour’d the reſt:
And ſuffer’d me by th’voyce of Slaues to be
Hoop’d out of Rome. Now this extremity,
Hath brought me to thy Harth, not out of Hope
(Miſtake me not) to ſaue my life: for if
I had fear’d death, of all the Men i’th’World
I would haue voided thee. But in meere ſpight
To be full quit of thoſe my Baniſhers,
Stand I before thee heere: Then if thou haſt
A heart of wreake in thee, that wilt reuenge
Thine owne particular wrongs, and ſtop thoſe maimes
Of ſhame ſeene through thy Country, ſpeed thee ſtraight
And make my miſery ſerue thy turne: So vſe it,
That my reuengefull Seruices may proue
As Benefits to thee. For I will fight
Againſt my Cankred Countrey, with the Spleene
Of all the vnder Fiends. But if ſo be,
Thou dar’ſt not this, and that to proue more Fortunes
Th’art tyr’d, then in a word, I alſo am
Longer to liue moſt wearie: and preſent
My throat to thee, and to thy Ancient Malice:
Which not to cut, would ſhew thee but a Foole,
Since I haue euer followed thee with hate,
Drawne Tunnes of Blood out of thy Countries breſt,
And cannot liue but to thy ſhame, vnleſſe
It be to do thee ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Oh Martius, Martius;
Each word thou haſt ſpoke, hath weeded from my heart
A roote of Ancient Enuy. If Iupiter
Should from yond clowd ſpeake diuine things,
And ſay ’tis true; I’de not beleeue them more
Then thee all-Noble Martius. Let me twine
Mine armes about that body, where againſt
My grained Aſh an hundred times hath broke,
And ſcarr’d the Moone with ſplinters: heere I cleep
The Anuile of my Sword, and do conteſt
As hotly, and as Nobly with thy Loue,
As euer in Ambitious ſtrength, I did
Contend againſt thy Valour. Know thou firſt,
I lou’d the Maid I married: neuer man
Sigh’d truer breath. But that I ſee thee heere
Thou Noble thing, more dances my rapt heart,
Then when I firſt my wedded Miſtris ſaw
Beſtride my Threſhold. Why, thou Mars I tell thee,
We haue a Power on foote: and I had purpoſe
Once more to hew thy Target from thy Brawne,
Or looſe mine Arme for’t: Thou haſt beate mee out
Twelue ſeuerall times, and I haue nightly ſince
Dreamt of encounters ’twixt thy ſelfe and me:
We haue beene downe together in my ſleepe,
Vnbuckling Helmes, fiſting each others Throat,
And wak’d halfe dead with nothing. Worthy Martius,
Had we no other quarrell elſe to Rome, but that
Thou art thence Baniſh’d, we would muſter all
From twelue, to ſeuentie: and powring Warre
Into the bowels of vngratefull Rome,
Like a bold Flood o’re-beate. Oh come, go in,
And take our friendly Senators by’th’hands
Who now are heere, taking their leaues of mee,
Who am prepar’d againſt your Territories,
Though not for Rome it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Corio.
speech.line: You bleſſe me Gods.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Therefore moſt abſolute Sir, if thou wilt haue
The leading of thine owne Reuenges, take
Th’one halfe of my Commiſſion, and ſet downe
As beſt thou art experienc’d, ſince thou know’ſt
Thy Countries ſtrength and weakneſſe, thine own waies
Whether to knocke againſt the Gates of Rome,
Or rudely viſit them in parts remote,
To fright them, ere deſtroy. But come in,
Let me commend thee firſt, to thoſe that ſhall
Say yea to thy deſires. A thouſand welcomes,
And more a Friend, then ere an Enemie,
Yet Martius that was much. Your hand: moſt welcome.
Heere’s a ſtrange alteration?
By my hand, I had thoght to haue ſtroken him with
a Cudgell, and yet my minde gaue me, his cloathes made
a falſe report of him.
What an Arme he has, he turn’d me about with his
finger and his thumbe, as one would ſet vp a Top.
Nay, I knew by his face that there was ſome-thing
in him. He had ſir, a kinde of face me thought, I cannot
tell how to tearme it.
He had ſo, looking as it were, would I were hang’d
but I thought there was more in him, then I could think.
So did I, Ile be ſworne: He is ſimply the rareſt man
i’th’world.
I thinke he is: but a greater ſoldier then he,
You wot one.
Who my Maſter?
Nay, it’s no matter for that.
Worth ſix on him.
Nay not ſo neither: but I take him to be the greater
Souldiour.
Faith looke you, one cannot tell how to ſay that: for
the Defence of a Towne, our Generall is excellent.
I, and for an aſſault too.
Oh Slaues, I can tell you Newes, News you Raſcals

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: What, what, what? Let’s partake.
I would not be a Roman of all Nations; I had as
liue be a condemn’d man.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Wherefore? Wherefore?
Why here’s he that was wont to thwacke our Ge—
nerall, Caius Martius.
Why do you ſay, thwacke our Generall?
I do not ſay thwacke our Generall, but he was al—
wayes good enough for him
Come we are fellowes and friends: he was euer too
hard for him, I haue heard him ſay ſo himſelfe.
He was too hard for him direƈtly, to ſay the Troth
on’t before Corioles, he ſcotcht him, and notcht him like a
Carbinado.
And hee had bin Cannibally giuen, hee might haue
boyld and eaten him too.
But more of thy Newes.
Why he is ſo made on heere within, as if hee were
Son and Heire to Mars, ſet at vpper end o’th’Table: No
queſtion askt him by any of the Senators, but they ſtand
bald before him. Our Generall himſelfe makes a Miſtris
of him, Sanƈtifies himſelfe with’s hand, and turnes vp the
white o’th’eye to his Diſcourſe. But the bottome of the
Newes is, our Generall is cut i’th’middle, & but one halfe
of what he was yeſterday. For the other ha’s halfe, by
the intreaty and graunt of the whole Table. Hee’l go he
ſayes, and ſole the Porter of Rome Gates by th’eares. He
will mowe all downe before him, and leaue his paſſage
poul’d.
And he’s as like to do’t, as any man I can imagine.
Doo’t? he will doo’t: for look you ſir, he has as ma—
ny Friends as Enemies: which Friends ſir as it were, durſt
not (looke you ſir) ſhew themſelues (as we terme it) his
Friends, whileſt he’s in Direƈtitude.
Direƈtitude? What’s that?
But when they ſhall ſee ſir, his Creſt vp againe, and
the man in blood, they will out of their Burroughes (like
Conies after Raine) and reuell all with him.
But when gœs this forward:
Tomorrow, to day, preſently, you ſhall haue the
Drum ſtrooke vp this afternoone: ’Tis as it were a parcel
of their Feaſt, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.
Why then wee ſhall haue a ſtirring World againe:
This peace is nothing, but to ruſt Iron, encreaſe Taylors,
and breed Ballad-makers.
Let me haue Warre ſay I, it exceeds peace as farre
as day do’s night: It’s ſprightly walking, audible, and full
of Vent. Peace, is a very Apoplexy, Lethargie, mull’d,
deafe, ſleepe, inſenſible, a getter of more baſtard Chil—
dren, then warres a deſtroyer of men.
’Tis ſo, and as warres in ſome ſort may be ſaide to
be a Rauiſher, ſo it cannot be denied, but peace is a great
maker of Cuckolds.
I, and it makes men hate one another.
Reaſon, becauſe they then leſſe neede one another:
The Warres for my money. I hope to ſee Romanes as
cheape as Volcians. They are riſing, they are riſing.

speech.speaker: Both
speech.line: In, in, in, in.

scene.stagedir: Enter the two Tribunes, Sicinius, and Brutus.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: We heare not of him, neither need we fear him,
His remedies are tame, the preſent peace,
And quietneſſe of the people, which before
Were in wilde hurry. Heere do we make his Friends
Bluſh, that the world gœs well: who rather had,
Though they themſelues did ſuffer by’t, behold
Diſſentious numbers peſtring ſtreets, then ſee
Our Tradeſmen ſinging in their ſhops, and going
About their Funƈtions friendly.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: We ſtood too’t in good time. Is this Menenius?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: ’Tis he, ’tis he: O he is grown moſt kind of late:
Haile Sir.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Haile to you both.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Your Coriolanus is not much miſt, but with his
Friends: the Commonwealth doth ſtand, and ſo would
do, were he more angry at it.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: All’s well, and might haue bene much better,
if he could haue temporiz’d.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Where is he, heare you?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Nay I heare nothing:
His Mother and his wife, heare nothing from him.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: The Gods preſerue you both.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Gooden our Neighbours.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Gooden to you all, gooden to you all.
Our ſelues, our wiues, and children, on our knees,
Are bound to pray for you both.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Liue, and thriue.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Farewell kinde Neighbours:
We wiſht Coriolanus had lou’d you as we did.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Now the Gods keepe you.

speech.speaker: Both Tri.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: This is a happier and more comely time,
Then when theſe Fellowes ran about the ſtreets,
Crying Confuſion.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Caius Martius was
A worthy Officer i’th’Warre, but Inſolent,
O’recome with Pride, Ambitious, paſt all thinking
Selfe-louing.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: And affeƈting one ſole Throne, without aſſiſtāce

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I thinke not ſo.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: We ſhould by this, to all our Lamention,
If he had gone forth Conſull, found it ſo.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: The Gods haue well preuented it, and Rome
Sits ſafe and ſtill, without him.

speech.speaker: Ædile.
speech.line: Worthy Tribunes,
There is a Slaue whom we haue put in priſon,
Reports the Volces with two ſeuerall Powers
Are entred in the Roman Territories,
And with the deepeſt malice of the Warre,
Deſtroy, what lies before ’em.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: ’Tis Auffidius,
Who hearing of our Martius Baniſhment,
Thruſts forth his hornes againe into the world
Which were In-shell’d, when Martius ſtood for Rome,
And durſt not once peepe out.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Come, what talke you of Martius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Go ſee this Rumorer whipt, it cannot be,
The Volces dare breake with vs.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Cannot be?
We haue Record, that very well it can,
And three examples of the like, hath beene
Within my Age. But reaſon with the fellow
Before you puniſh him, where he heard this,
Leaſt you ſhall chance to whip your Information,
And beate the Meſſenger, who bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Tell not me: I know this cannot be.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Not poſſible.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: The Nobles in great earneſtneſſe are going
All to the Senate-houſe: ſome newes is comming
That turnes their Countenances.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: ’Tis this Slaue:
Go whip him fore the peoples eyes: His raiſing,
Nothing but his report.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Yes worthy Sir,
The Slaues report is ſeconded, and more
More fearfull is deliuer’d.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: What more fearefull?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: It is ſpoke freely out of many mouths,
How probable I do not know, that Martius
Ioyn’d with Auffidius, leads a power ’gainſt Rome,
And vowes Reuenge as ſpacious, as betweene
The yong’ſt and oldeſt thing.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: This is moſt likely.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Rais’d onely, that the weaker ſort may wiſh
Good Martius home againe.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: The very tricke on’t.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: This is vnlikely,
He, and Auffidius can no more attone
Then violent’ſt Contrariety.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: You are ſent for to the Senate:
A fearefull Army, led by Caius Martius,
Aſſociated with Auffidius, Rages
Vpon our Territories, and haue already
O’re-borne their way, conſum’d with fire, and tooke
What lay before them.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Oh you haue made good worke.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: What newes? What newes?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: You haue holp to rauiſh your owne daughters, &
To melt the Citty Leades vpon your pates,
To ſee your Wiues diſhonour’d to your Noſes.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: What’s the newes? What’s the newes?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Your Temples burned in their Ciment, and
Your Franchiſes, whereon you ſtood, confin’d
Into an Augors boare.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Pray now, your Newes:
You haue made faire worke I feare me: pray your newes,
If Martius ſhould be ioyn’d with Volceans.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: If? He is their God, he leads them like a thing
Made by ſome other Deity then Nature,
That ſhapes man Better: and they follow him
Againſt vs Brats, with no leſſe Confidence,
Then Boyes purſuing Summer Butter-flies,
Or Butchers killing Flyes.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You haue made good worke,
You and your Apron men: you, that ſtood ſo much
Vpon the voyce of occupation, and
The breath of Garlicke-eaters.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Hee’l ſhake your Rome about your eares.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: As Hercules did ſhake downe Mellow Fruite:
You haue made faire worke.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: But is this true ſir?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I, and you’l looke pale
Before you finde it other. All the Regions
Do ſmilingly Reuolt, and who reſiſts
Are mock’d for valiant Ignorance,
And periſh conſtant Fooles: who is’t can blame him?
Your Enemies and his, finde ſomething in him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: We are all vndone, vnleſſe
The Noble man haue mercy.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Who ſhall aske it?
The Tribunes cannot doo’t for ſhame; the people
Deſerue ſuch pitty of him, as the Wolfe
Dœ’s of the Shepheards: For his beſt Friends, if they
Should ſay be good to Rome, they charg’d him, euen
As thoſe ſhould do that had deſeru’d his hate,
And therein ſhew’d like Enemies.

speech.speaker: Me.
speech.line: ’Tis true, if he were putting to my houſe, the brand
That ſhould conſume it, I haue not the face
To ſay, beſeech you ceaſe. You haue made faire hands,
You and your Crafts, you haue crafted faire.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: You haue brought
A Trembling vpon Rome, ſuch as was neuer
S’incapeable of helpe.

speech.speaker: Tri.
speech.line: Say not, we brought it.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: How? Was’t we? We lou’d him,
But like Beaſts, and Cowardly Nobles,
Gaue way vnto your Cluſters, who did hoote
Him out o’th’Citty.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: But I feare
They’l roare him in againe. Tullus Affidius,
The ſecond name of men, obeyes his points
As if he were his Officer: Deſperation,
Is all the Policy, Strength, and Defence
That Rome can make againſt them.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Heere come the Cluſters.
And is Auffidius with him? You are they
That made the Ayre vnwholſome, when you caſt
Your ſtinking, greaſie Caps, in hooting
At Coriolanus Exile. Now he’s comming,
And not a haire vpon a Souldiers head
Which will not proue a whip: As many Coxcombes
As you threw Caps vp, will he tumble downe,
And pay you for your voyces. ’Tis no matter,
If he could burne vs all into one coale,
We haue deſeru’d it.

speech.speaker: Omnes.
speech.line: Faith, we heare fearfull Newes.

speech.speaker: 1 Cit.
speech.line: For mine owne part,
When I ſaid baniſh him, I ſaid ’twas pitty.
And ſo did I.
And ſo did I: and to ſay the truth, ſo did very ma—
ny of vs, that we did we did for the beſt, and though wee
willingly conſented to his Baniſhment, yet it was againſt
our will.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Y’are goodly things, you Voyces.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You haue made good worke
You and your cry. Shal’s to the Capitoll?

speech.speaker: Com
speech.line: Oh I, what elſe?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Go Maſters get you home, be not diſmaid,
Theſe are a Side, that would be glad to haue
This true, which they ſo ſeeme to feare. Go home,
And ſhew no ſigne of Feare.

speech.speaker: 1 Cit.
speech.line: The Gods bee good to vs: Come Maſters let’s
home, I euer ſaid we were i’th wrong, when we baniſh’d
him.

speech.speaker: 2 Cit.
speech.line: So did we all. But come, let’s home.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I do not like this Newes.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Let’s to the Capitoll: would halfe my wealth
Would buy this for a lye.

speech.speaker: Sicin
speech.line: Pray let’s go.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: Do they ſtill flye to’th’Roman?

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: I do not know what Witchcraft’s in him: but
Your Soldiers vſe him as the Grace ’fore meate,
Their talke at Table, and their Thankes at end,
And you are darkned in this aƈtion Sir,
Euen by your owne.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: I cannot helpe it now,
Vnleſſe by vſing meanes I lame the foote
Of our deſigne. He beares himſelfe more proudlier,
Euen to my perſon, then I thought he would
When firſt I did embrace him. Yet his Nature
In that’s no Changeling, and I muſt excuſe
What cannot be amended.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Yet I wiſh Sir,
(I meane for your particular) you had not
Ioyn’d in Commiſſion with him: but either haue borne
The aƈtion of your ſelfe, or elſe to him, had left it ſoly.

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: I vnderſtand thee well, and be thou ſure
When he ſhall come to his account, he knowes not
What I can vrge againſt him, although it ſeemes
And ſo he thinkes, and is no leſſe apparant
To th’vulgar eye, that he beares all things fairely:
And ſhewes good Husbandry for the Volcian State,
Fights Dragon-like, and dœs atcheeue as ſoone
As draw his Sword: yet he hath left vndone
That which ſhall breake his necke, or hazard mine,
When ere we come to our account.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Sir, I beſeech you, think you he’l carry Rome?

speech.speaker: Auf.
speech.line: All places yeelds to him ere he ſits downe,
And the Nobility of Rome are his:
The Senators and Patricians loue him too:
The Tribunes are no Soldiers: and their people
Will be as raſh in the repeale, as haſty
To expell him thence. I thinke hee’l be to Rome
As is the Aſpray to the Fiſh, who takes it
By Soueraignty of Nature. Firſt, he was
A Noble ſeruant to them, but he could not
Carry his Honors eeuen: whether ’was Pride
Which out of dayly Fortune euer taints
The happy man; whether deteƈt of iudgement,
To faile in the diſpoſing of thoſe chances
Which he was Lord of: or whether Nature,
Not to be other then one thing, not moouing
From th’Caske to th’Cuſhion: but commanding peace
Euen with the ſame auſterity and garbe,
As he controll’d the warre. But one of theſe
(As he hath ſpices of them all) not all,
For I dare ſo farre free him, made him fear’d,
So hated, and ſo baniſh’d: but he ha’s a Merit
To choake it in the vtt’rance: So our Vertue,
Lie in th’interpretation of the time,
And power vnto it ſelfe moſt commendable,
Hath not a Tombe ſo euident as a Chaire
T’extoll what it hath done.
One fire driues out one fire; one Naile, one Naile;
Rights by rights fouler, ſtrengths by ſtrengths do faile.
Come let’s away: when Caius Rome is thine,
Thou art poor’ſt of all; then ſhortly art thou mine.

scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius, Cominius, Sicinius, Brutus, the two Tribunes, with others.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: No, ile not go: you heare what he hath ſaid
Which was ſometime his Generall: who loued him
In a moſt deere particular. He call’d me Father:
But what o’that? Go you that baniſh’d him
A Mile before his Tent, fall downe, and knee
The way into his mercy: Nay, if he coy’d
To heare Cominius ſpeake, Ile keepe at home.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: He would not ſeeme to know me.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Do you heare?

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Yet one time he did call me by my name:
I vrg’d our old acquaintance, and the drops
That we haue bled together. Coriolanus
He would not anſwer too: Forbad all Names,
He was a kinde of Nothing, Titleleſſe,
Till he had forg’d himſelfe a name a’th’fire
Of burning Rome.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Why ſo: you haue made good worke:
A paire of Tribunes, that haue wrack’d for Rome,
To make Coales cheape: A Noble memory.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I minded him, how Royall ’twas to pardon
When it was leſſe expeƈted. He replyed
It was a bare petition of a State
To one whom they had puniſh’d.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: Very well, could he ſay leſſe.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I offered to awaken his regard
For’s priuate Friends. His anſwer to me was
He could not ſtay to picke them, in a pile
Of noyſome muſty Chaffe. He ſaid, ’twas folly
For one poore graine or two, to leaue vnburnt
And ſtill to noſe th’offence.

speech.speaker: Menen.
speech.line: For one poore graine or two?
I am one of thoſe: his Mother, Wife, his Childe,
And this braue Fellow too: we are the Graines,
You are the muſty Chaffe, and you are ſmelt
Aboue the Moone. We muſt be burnt for you.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Nay, pray be patient: If you refuſe your ayde
In this ſo neuer-needed helpe, yet do not
Vpbraid’s with our diſtreſſe. But ſure if you
Would be your Countries Pleader, your good tongue
More then the inſtant Armie we can make
Might ſtop our Countryman.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: No: Ile not meddle.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Pray you go to him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: What ſhould I do?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Onely make triall what your Loue can do,
For Rome, towards Martius.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Well, and ſay that Martius returne mee,
As Cominius is return’d, vnheard: what then?
But as a diſcontented Friend, greefe-shot
With his vnkindneſſe. Say’t be ſo?

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Yet your good will
Muſt haue that thankes from Rome, after the meaſure
As you intended well.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile vndertak’t:
I thinke hee’l heare me. Yet to bite his lip,
And humme at good Cominius, much vnhearts mee.
He was not taken well, he had not din’d,
The Veines vnfill’d, our blood is cold, and then
We powt vpon the Morning, are vnapt
To giue or to forgiue; but when we haue ſtufft
Theſe Pipes, and theſe Conueyances of our blood
With Wine and Feeding, we haue ſuppler Soules
Then in our Prieſt-like Faſts: therefore Ile watch him
Till he be dieted to my requeſt,
And then Ile ſet vpon him.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You know the very rode into his kindneſſe,
And cannot loſe your way.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Good faith Ile proue him,
Speed how it will. I ſhall ere long, haue knowledge
Of my ſucceſſe.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: Hee’l neuer heare him.

speech.speaker: Sicin.
speech.line: Not.

speech.speaker: Com.
speech.line: I tell you, he dœ’s ſit in Gold, his eye
Red as ’twould burne Rome: and his Iniury
The Gaoler to his pitty. I kneel’d before him,
’Twas very faintly he ſaid Riſe: diſmiſt me
Thus with his ſpeechleſſe hand. What he would do
He ſent in writing after me: what he would not,
Bound with an Oath to yeeld to his conditions:
So that all hope is vaine, vnleſſe his Noble Mother,
And his Wife, who (as I heare) meane to ſolicite him
For mercy to his Countrey: therefore let’s hence,
And with our faire intreaties haſt them on.

scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius to the Watch or Guard.

speech.speaker: 1.Wat.
speech.line: Stay: whence are you.

speech.speaker: 2.Wat.
speech.line: Stand, and go backe.

speech.speaker: Me.
speech.line: You guard like men, ’tis well. But by your leaue,
I am an Officer of State, & come to ſpeak with Coriolanus
From whence?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: From Rome.

speech.speaker: I
speech.line: You may not paſſe, you muſt returne: our Generall
will no more heare from thence.
You’l ſee your Rome embrac’d with fire, before
You’l ſpeake with Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Good my Friends,
If you haue heard your Generall talke of Rome,
And of his Friends there, it is Lots to Blankes,
My name hath touch’t your eares: it is Menenius.
Be it ſo, go back: the vertue of your name,
Is not heere paſſable.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I tell thee Fellow,
Thy Generall is my Louer: I haue beene
The booke of his good Aƈts, whence men haue read
His Fame vnparalell’d, happely amplified:
For I haue euer verified my Friends,
(Of whom hee’s cheefe) with all the ſize that verity
Would without lapſing ſuffer: Nay, ſometimes,
Like to a Bowle vpon a ſubtle ground
I haue tumbled paſt the throw: and in his praiſe
Haue (almoſt) ſtampt the Leaſing. Therefore Fellow,
I muſt haue leaue to paſſe.
Faith Sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalfe,
as you haue vttered words in your owne, you ſhould not
paſſe heere: no, though it were as vertuous to lye, as to
liue chaſtly. Therefore go backe.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Prythee fellow, remember my name is Menenius,
alwayes faƈtionary on the party of your Generall.
Howsœuer you haue bin his Lier, as you ſay you
haue, I am one that telling true vnder him, muſt ſay you
cannot paſſe. Therefore go backe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ha’s he din’d can’ſt thou tell? For I would not
ſpeake with him, till after dinner.
You are a Roman, are you?

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I am as thy Generall is.
Then you ſhould hate Rome, as he do’s. Can you,
when you haue puſht out your gates, the very Defender
of them, and in a violent popular ignorance, giuen your
enemy your ſhield, thinke to front his reuenges with the
eaſie groanes of old women, the Virginall Palms of your
daughters, or with the palſied interceſſion of ſuch a de—
cay’d Dotant as you ſeeme to be? Can you think to blow
out the intended fire, your City is ready to flame in, with
ſuch weake breath as this? No, you are deceiu’d, therfore
backe to Rome, and prepare for your execution: you are
condemn’d, our Generall has ſworne you out of repreeue
and pardon.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Sirra, if thy Captaine knew I were heere,
He would vſe me with eſtimation.
